1	A			RFCs from 1969							"Host Software" was released in April of 1969 by S. Crocker. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc1.txt

674	A			RFCs from 1974							"Procedure call documents: Version 2" was released in December of 1974 by J.E. White, and J. Postel. Host level protocol used in the NSW--a slightly constrained version of ARPANET Host-to-Host protocol, affecting allocation, RFNM wait, and retransmission; see also RFC 684.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc674.txt
675	A			RFCs from 1974							"Specification of Internet Transmission Control Program" was released in December of 1974 by C. Sunshine, V. Cerf, and Y. Dalal. The first detailed specification of TCP; see RFC 793.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc675.txt
677	A			RFCs from 1975							"Maintenance of duplicate databases" was released in January of 1975 by R. Thomas, and P.R. Johnson. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc677.txt
678	A			RFCs from 1974							"Standard file formats" was released in December of 1974 by J. Postel. For transmission of documents across different environments.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc678.txt
679	A			RFCs from 1975							"February, 1975, survey of New-Protocol Telnet servers" was released in February of 1975 by D.W. Dodds. An earlier poll of Telnet server implementation status.  Updates RFCs 701, 702 and 669; see also RFC 703.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc679.txt
680	A			RFCs from 1975							"Message Transmission Protocol" was released in April of 1975 by D.A. Henderson, and T.H. Myer. Extends message field definition beyond RFC 561 attempts to establish syntactic and semantic standards for ARPANET; see also RFCs 733 and 822.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc680.txt
681	A			RFCs from 1975							"Network UNIX" was released in March of 1975 by S. Holmgren. Capabilities as an ARPANET Mini-Host: standard I/O, Telnet, NCP, Hardware/Software requirements, reliability, availability.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc681.txt
683	A			RFCs from 1975							"FTPSRV - Tenex extension for paged files" was released in April of 1975 by R. Clements. Defines an extension to FTP for page-mode transfers between TENEX systems; also discusses file transfer reliability.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc683.txt
684	A			RFCs from 1975							"Commentary on procedure calling as a network protocol" was released in April of 1975 by R. Schantz. Issues in designing distributed computing systems.  Shortcomings of RFC 674; see also RFCs 542 and 354.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc684.txt
685	A			RFCs from 1975							"Response time in cross network debugging" was released in April of 1975 by M. Beeler. The contribution of ARPANET communication to response time.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc685.txt
686	A			RFCs from 1975							"Leaving well enough alone" was released in May of 1975 by B. Harvey. Discusses difference between early and later versions of FTP; see also RFCs 691, 640, 630, 542, 454, 448, 414, 385 and 354.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc686.txt
687	A			RFCs from 1975							"IMP/Host and Host/IMP Protocol changes" was released in June of 1975 by D.C. Walden. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+704">RFC 704</a>. Addressing hosts on more than 63 IMPs, and other backwards compatible expansions; see also RFCs 690 and 692.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc687.txt
688	A			RFCs from 1975							"Tentative schedule for the new Telnet implementation for the TIP" was released in June of 1975 by D.C. Walden. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc688.txt
689	A			RFCs from 1975							"Tenex NCP finite state machine for connections" was released in May of 1975 by R. Clements. Describes the internal states of an NCP connection in the TENEX implementation.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc689.txt
690	A			RFCs from 1975							"Comments on the proposed Host/IMP Protocol changes" was released in June of 1975 by J. Postel. Comments on suggestions in RFC 687; see also RFCs 692 and 696.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc690.txt
691	A			RFCs from 1975							"One more try on the FTP" was released in June of 1975 by B. Harvey. Slight revision of RFC 686, on the subject of print files; see also RFCs 640, 630, 542, 454, 448, 414, 385 and 354.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc691.txt
692	A			RFCs from 1975							"Comments on IMP/Host Protocol changes (RFCs 687 and 690)" was released in June of 1975 by S.M. Wolfe. A proposed solution to the problem of combined length of IMP and Host leaders; see also RFCs 696, 690 and 687.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc692.txt
694	A			RFCs from 1975							"Protocol information" was released in June of 1975 by J. Postel. References to documents and contacts concerning the various protocols used in the ARPANET, as well as recent developments; updates RFC 661.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc694.txt
695	A			RFCs from 1975							"Official change in Host-Host Protocol" was released in July of 1975 by M. Krilanovich. Corrects ambiguity concerning the ERR command; changes NIC 8246 and NIC 7104.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc695.txt
696	A			RFCs from 1975							"Comments on the IMP/Host and Host/IMP Protocol changes" was released in July of 1975 by V.G. Cerf. Observations on current international standards recommendations from IFIP working group 6.1; see also RFCs 692, 690, 687.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc696.txt
697	A			RFCs from 1975							"CWD command of FTP" was released in July of 1975 by J. Lieb. Discusses FTP login access to "files only" directories.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc697.txt
698	A			RFCs from 1975							"Telnet extended ASCII option" was released in July of 1975 by T. Mock. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5198">RFC 5198</a>. Describes an option to allow transmission of a special kind of extended ASCII used at the Stanford AI and MIT AI Labs.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc698.txt
699	A			RFCs from 1982							"Request For Comments summary notes: 600-699" was released in November of 1982 by J. Vernon, and J. Postel. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc699.txt
700	A			RFCs from 1974							"Protocol experiment" was released in August of 1974 by R.S. Tomlinson, W.W. Plummer, and E. Mader. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc700.txt

797	A			RFCs from 1981							"Format for Bitmap files" was released in September of 1981 by A.R. Katz. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc797.txt
798	A			RFCs from 1981							"Decoding facsimile data from the Rapicom 450" was released in September of 1981 by A.R. Katz. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc798.txt
799	A			RFCs from 1981							"Internet name domains" was released in September of 1981 by D.L. Mills. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc799.txt
800	A			RFCs from 1982							"Request For Comments summary notes: 700-799" was released in November of 1982 by J. Vernon, and J. Postel. This RFC is a slightly annotated list of the 100 RFCs from RFC 700 through RFC 799.  This is a status report on these RFCs.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc800.txt
801	A			RFCs from 1981							"NCP/TCP transition plan" was released in November of 1981 by J. Postel. This RFC discusses the conversion of hosts from NCP to TCP.  And making available the principle services: Telnet, File Transfer, and Mail.  These protocols allow all hosts in the ARPA community to share a common interprocess communication environment.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc801.txt
802	A			RFCs from 1981							"ARPANET 1822L Host Access Protocol" was released in November of 1981 by A.G. Malis. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+851">RFC 851</a>. This document proposed two major changes to the current ARPANET host access protocol.  The first change will allow hosts to use logical addressing (i.e., host addresses that are independent of their physical location on the ARPANET) to communicate with each other, and the second will allow a host to shorten the amount of time that it may be blocked by its IMP after it presents a message to the network (currently, the IMP can block further input from a host for up to 15 seconds).  See RFCs 852 and 851.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc802.txt
803	A			RFCs from 1981							"Dacom 450/500 facsimile data transcoding" was released in November of 1981 by A. Agarwal, D.L. Mills, and M.J. O'Connor. The first part of this RFC describes in detail the Dacom 450 data compression algorithms and is an update and correction to an earlier memorandum.  The second part of this RFC describes briefly the Dacom 500 data compression algorithm as used by the INTELPOST electronic-mail network under development by the US Postal Service and several foreign administrators.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc803.txt
804	A			RFCs from 1981							"CCITT draft recommendation T.4" was released in January of 1981 by International Telegraph and Telephone Consultative Committee of the International Telecommunication Union. This is the CCITT standard for group 3 facsimile encoding.  This is useful for data compression of bit map data.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc804.txt
805	A			RFCs from 1982							"Computer mail meeting notes" was released in February of 1982 by J. Postel. This RFC consists of notes from a meeting that was held at USC Information Sciences Institute on 11 January 1982, to discuss addressing issues in computer mail.  The major conclusion reached at the meeting is to extend the "username@hostname" mailbox format to "username@host.domain", where the domain itself can be further strutured.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc805.txt
806	A			RFCs from 1981							"Proposed Federal Information Processing Standard: Specification for message format for computer based message systems" was released in September of 1981 by National Bureau of Standards. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+841">RFC 841</a>. This RFC deals with Computer Based Message systems which provides a basis for interaction between different CBMS by defining the format of messages passed between them.  This RFC is replaced by RFC 841.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc806.txt
807	A			RFCs from 1982							"Multimedia mail meeting notes" was released in February of 1982 by J. Postel. This RFC consists of notes from a meeting held at USC Information Sciences Institute on the 12th of January to discuss common interests in multimedia computer mail issues and to agree on some specific initial experiments.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc807.txt
808	A			RFCs from 1982							"Summary of computer mail services meeting held at BBN on 10 January 1979" was released in March of 1982 by J. Postel. This RFC is a very belated attempt to document a meeting that was held three years earlier to discuss the state of computer mail in the ARPA community and to reach some conclusions to guide the further development of computer mail systems such that a coherent total mail service would continue to be provided.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc808.txt
809	A			RFCs from 1982							"UCL facsimile system" was released in February of 1982 by T. Chang. This RFC describes the features of the computerised facsimile system developed in the Department of Computer Science at UCL.  First its functions are considered and the related experimental work are reported.  Then the disciplines for system design are discussed.  Finally, the implementation of the system are described, while detailed description are given as appendices.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc809.txt
810	A			RFCs from 1982							"DoD Internet host table specification" was released in March of 1982 by V. White, E.J. Feinler, Z. Su, and K. Harrenstien. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+608">RFC 608</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+952">RFC 952</a>. This RFC specifies a new host table format applicable to both ARPANET and Internet needs.  In addition to host name to host address translation and selected protocol information, we have also included network and gateway name to address correspondence, and host operating system information.  This RFC obsoletes the host table described in RFC 608.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc810.txt
811	A			RFCs from 1982							"Hostnames Server" was released in March of 1982 by E.J. Feinler, V. White, and K. Harrenstien. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+953">RFC 953</a>. This RFC gives a description of what the Hostnames Server is and how to access it.  The function of this particular server is to deliver machine-readable name/address information describing networks, gateways, hosts, and eventually domains, within the internet environment.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc811.txt
812	A			RFCs from 1982							"NICNAME/WHOIS" was released in March of 1982 by V. White, and K. Harrenstien. This RFC gives a description of what the NICNAME/WHOIS Server is and how to access it.  This server together with the corresponding Identification Data Base provides online directory look-up equivalent to the ARPANET Directory.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc812.txt
813	A			RFCs from 1982							"Window and Acknowledgement Strategy in TCP" was released in July of 1982 by D.D. Clark. This RFC describes implementation strategies to deal with two mechanisms in TCP, the window and the acknowledgement.  It also presents a particular set of algorithms which have received testing in the field, and which appear to work properly with each other.  With more experience, these algorithms may become part of the formal specification, until such time their use is recommended.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc813.txt
814	A			RFCs from 1982							"Name, addresses, ports, and routes" was released in July of 1982 by D.D. Clark. This RFC gives suggestions and guidance for the design of the tables and algorithms necessary to keep track of these various sorts of identifiers inside a host implementation of TCP/IP.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc814.txt
815	A			RFCs from 1982							"IP datagram reassembly algorithms" was released in July of 1982 by D.D. Clark. This RFC describes an alternate approach of dealing with reassembly which reduces the bookkeeping problem to a minimum, and requires only one buffer for storage equal in size to the final datagram being reassembled, which can reassemble a datagram from any number of fragments arriving in any order with any possible pattern of overlap and duplication, and which is appropriate for almost any sort of operating system.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc815.txt
816	A			RFCs from 1982							"Fault isolation and recovery" was released in July of 1982 by D.D. Clark. This RFC describes the portion of fault isolation and recovery which is the responsibility of the host.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc816.txt
817	A			RFCs from 1982							"Modularity and efficiency in protocol implementation" was released in July of 1982 by D.D. Clark. This RFC will discuss some of the commonly encountered reasons why protocol implementations seem to run slowly.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc817.txt
818	A			RFCs from 1982							"Remote User Telnet service" was released in November of 1982 by J. Postel. This RFC is the specification of an application protocol.  Any host that implements this application level service must follow this protocol.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc818.txt
819	A			RFCs from 1982							"Domain naming convention for Internet user applications" was released in August of 1982 by J. Postel, and Z. Su. This RFC is an attempt to clarify the generalization of the Domain Naming Convention, the Internet Naming Convention, and to explore the implications of its adoption for Internet name service and user applications.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc819.txt
820	A			RFCs from 1982							"Assigned numbers" was released in August of 1982 by J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+790">RFC 790</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+870">RFC 870</a>. This RFC is an old version, see RFC 870.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc820.txt
821	A			RFCs from 1982							"Simple Mail Transfer Protocol" was released in August of 1982 by J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+788">RFC 788</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2821">RFC 2821</a>. The objective of Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) is to transfer mail reliably and efficiently.  SMTP is independent of the particular transmission subsystem and requires only a reliable ordered data stream channel.  Obsoletes RFC 788, 780, and 772.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc821.txt
822	A			RFCs from 1982							"STANDARD FOR THE FORMAT OF ARPA INTERNET TEXT MESSAGES" was released in August of 1982 by D. Crocker. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+733">RFC 733</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2822">RFC 2822</a>. This document revises the specifications in RFC 733, in order to serve the needs of the larger and more complex ARPA Internet.  Some of RFC 733's features failed to gain adequate acceptance.  In order to simplify the standard and the software that follows it, these features have been removed.  A different addressing scheme is used, to handle the case of internetwork mail; and the concept of re-transmission has been introduced.  Obsoletes RFC 733, NIC 41952.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc822.txt
823	A			RFCs from 1982							"DARPA Internet gateway" was released in September of 1982 by R.M. Hinden, and A. Sheltzer. This RFC is a status report on the Internet Gateway developed by BBN.  It describes the Internet Gateway as of September 1982.  This memo presents detailed descriptions of message formats and gateway procedures, however, this is not an implementation specification, and such details are subject to change.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc823.txt
824	A			RFCs from 1982							"CRONUS Virtual Local Network" was released in August of 1982 by D.C. Tappan, and W.I. MacGregor. The purpose of this note is to describe the CRONUS Virtual Local Network, especially the addressing related features.  These features include a method for mapping between Internet Addresses and Local Network addresses.  This is a topic of current concern in the ARPA Internet community.  This note is intended to stimulate discussion.  This is not a specification of an Internet Standard.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc824.txt
825	A			RFCs from 1982							"Request for comments on Requests For Comments" was released in November of 1982 by J. Postel. This RFC is intended to clarify the status of RFCs and to provide some guidance for the authors of RFCs in the future.  It is in a sense a specification for RFCs.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc825.txt
826	A			RFCs from 1982							"Ethernet Address Resolution Protocol: Or Converting Network Protocol Addresses to 48.bit Ethernet Address for Transmission on Ethernet Hardware" was released in November of 1982 by D. Plummer. The purpose of this RFC is to present a method of Converting Protocol Addresses (e.g., IP addresses) to Local Network Addresses (e.g., Ethernet addresses).  This is an issue of general concern in the ARPA Internet Community at this time.  The method proposed here is presented for your consideration and comment.  This is not the specification of an Internet Standard.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc826.txt

This RFC is proposed to establish a standard for Gateway to Gateway procedures that allow the Gateways to be mutually suspicious.  This document is a DRAFT for that standard.  Your comments are strongly encouraged.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc827.txt

831	A			RFCs from 1982							"Backup access to the European side of SATNET" was released in December of 1982 by R.T. Braden. The purpose of this RFC is to focus discussion on a particular Internet problem: a backup path for software maintenance of the European sector of the Internet, for use when SATNET is partitioned.  We propose a mechanism, based upon the Source Routing option of IP, to reach European Internet sites via the VAN Gateway and UCL.  This proposal is not intended as a standard at this time.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc831.txt

844	A			RFCs from 1983							"Who talks ICMP, too? - Survey of 18 February 1983" was released in February of 1983 by R. Clements. This survey determines how many hosts are able to respond to TELENET connections from a user at a class C site.  This requires, in addition to IP and TCP, participation in gateway routing via ICMP and handling of Class C addresses.  The list of hosts was taken from RFC 843, extracting only those hosts which are listed there as accepting TELNET connection.  The tests were run on 18-Feb-83.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc844.txt

847	A			RFCs from 1983							"Summary of Smallberg surveys" was released in February of 1983 by D. Smallberg, J. Postel, and A. Westine. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+846">RFC 846</a>. This is a summary of the surveys of Telnet, FTP and Mail (SMTP) servers conducted by David Smallberg in December 1982, January and February 1983 as reported in RFC 832-843, 845-846.  This memo extracts the number of hosts that accepted the connection to their server for each of Telnet, FTP, and SMTP, and compares it to the total host in the Internet (not counting TACs or ECHOS).	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc847.txt

849	A			RFCs from 1983							"Suggestions for improved host table distribution" was released in May of 1983 by M.R. Crispin. This RFC actually is a request for comments.  The issue dealt with is that of a naming registry update procedure, both as exists currently and what could exist in the future.  None of the proposed solutions are intended as standards at this time; rather it is hoped that a general consensus will emerge as the appropriate solution, leaving eventually to the adoption of standards.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc849.txt
850	A			RFCs from 1983							"Standard for interchange of USENET messages" was released in June of 1983 by M.R. Horton. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+1036">RFC 1036</a>. This memo is distributed as an RFC only to make this information easily accessible to researchers in the ARPA community.  It does not specify an Internet standard.  This RFC defines the standard format for interchange of Network News articles among USENET sites.  It describes the format for articles themselves, and gives partial standards for transmission of news.  The news transmission is not entirely standardized in order to give a good deal of flexibility to the individual hosts to choose transmission hardware and software, whether to batch news and so on.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc850.txt
851	A			RFCs from 1983							"ARPANET 1822L Host Access Protocol" was released in April of 1983 by A.G. Malis. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+802">RFC 802</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+878">RFC 878</a>. This RFC specifies the ARPANET 1822L Host Access Protocol, which is a successor to the existing 1822 Host Access Protocol.  1822L allows ARPANET hosts to use logical names as well as 1822's physical port locations to address each other.  This RFC is also being presented as a solicitation of comments on 1822L, especially from host network software implementers and maintainers.  Obsoletes RFC 802.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc851.txt
852	A			RFCs from 1983							"ARPANET short blocking feature" was released in April of 1983 by A.G. Malis. This RFC specifies the ARPANET Short Blocking Feature, which will allow ARPANET hosts to optionally shorten the IMP's host blocking timer.  This Feature is a replacement of the ARPANET non-blocking host interface, which was never implemented, and will be available to hosts using either the 1822 or 1822L Host Access Protocol.  This RFC is also being presented as a solicitation of comments on the Short Blocking Feature, especially from host network software implementers and maintainers.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc852.txt
854	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Protocol Specification" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+764">RFC 764</a>. This is the specification of the Telnet protocol used for remote terminal access in the ARPA Internet.  The purpose of the TELNET Protocol is to provide a fairly general, bi-directional, eight-bit byte oriented communications facility.  Its primary goal is to allow a standard method of interfacing terminal devices and terminal-oriented processes to each other.  It is envisioned that the protocol may also be used for terminal-terminal communication ("linking") and process-process communication (distributed computation).  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes NIC 18639.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc854.txt
855	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Option Specifications" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+18640">RFC 18640</a>. This memo specifies the general form for Telnet options and the directions for their specification.  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes RFC 651, NIC 18640.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc855.txt
856	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Binary Transmission" was released in May of 1983 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+15389">RFC 15389</a>. This Telnet Option enables a binary data mode between the Telnet modules.  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes NIC 15389.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc856.txt
857	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Echo Option" was released in May of 1983 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+15390">RFC 15390</a>. This Telnet Option enables remote echoing by the other Telnet module.  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes NIC 15390.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc857.txt
858	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Suppress Go Ahead Option" was released in May of 1983 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+15392">RFC 15392</a>. This Telnet Option disables the exchange of go-ahead signals between the Telnet modules.  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes NIC 15392.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc858.txt
859	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Status Option" was released in May of 1983 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+651">RFC 651</a>. This Telnet Option provides a way to determine the other Telnet module's view of the status of options.  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes RFC 651 (NIC 31154).	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc859.txt
860	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Timing Mark Option" was released in May of 1983 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+16238">RFC 16238</a>. This Telnet Option provides a way to check the roundtrip path between two Telnet modules.  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes NIC 16238.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc860.txt
861	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet Extended Options: List Option" was released in May of 1983 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+16239">RFC 16239</a>. This Telnet Option provides a mechanism for extending the set of possible options.  This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  Obsoletes NIC 16239.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc861.txt
862	A			RFCs from 1983							"Echo Protocol" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that choose to implement a Echo Protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  The Echo service simply sends back to the originating source any data it receives.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc862.txt
863	A			RFCs from 1983							"Discard Protocol" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that choose to implement a Discard Protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  The Discard service simply throws away any data it receives.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc863.txt
864	A			RFCs from 1983							"Character Generator Protocol" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that choose to implement a Character Generator Protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  The Character Generator service simply sends data without regard to the input.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc864.txt
865	A			RFCs from 1983							"Quote of the Day Protocol" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that choose to implement a Quote of the Day Protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  The Quote of the Day service simply sends a short message without regard to the input.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc865.txt
866	A			RFCs from 1983							"Active users" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that choose to implement an Active Users Protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  The Active Users service simply sends a list of the currently active users on the host without regard to the input.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc866.txt
867	A			RFCs from 1983							"Daytime Protocol" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that choose to implement a Daytime Protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  The Daytime service simply sends the current date and time as a character string without regard to the input.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc867.txt
868	A			RFCs from 1983							"Time Protocol" was released in May of 1983 by J. Postel, and K. Harrenstien. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that choose to implement a Time Protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  This protocol provides a site-independent, machine readable date and time.  The Time service sends back to the originating source the time in seconds since midnight on January first 1900.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc868.txt
869	A			RFCs from 1983							"Host Monitoring Protocol" was released in December of 1983 by R. Hinden. This RFC specifies the Host Monitoring Protocol used to collect information from various types of hosts in the Internet.  Designers of Internet communications software are encouraged to consider this protocol as a means of monitoring the behavior of their creations.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc869.txt
870	A			RFCs from 1983							"Assigned numbers" was released in October of 1983 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+820">RFC 820</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+900">RFC 900</a>. This RFC documents the list of numbers assigned for networks, protocols, etc.  Obsoletes RFCs 820, 790, 776, 770, 762, 758, 755, 750, 739, 604.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc870.txt
871	A			RFCs from 1982							"Perspective on the ARPANET reference model" was released in September of 1982 by M.A. Padlipsky. This RFC is primarily intended as a perspective on the ARM and points out some of the differences between the ARM and the ISORM which were expressed by members in NWG general meetings, NWG protocol design committee meetings, the ARPA Internet Working Group, and private conversations over the intervening years.  Originally published as M82-47 by the MITRE Corporation, Bedford, Massachusetts.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc871.txt
872	A			RFCs from 1982							"TCP-on-a-LAN" was released in September of 1982 by M.A. Padlipsky. This memo attacks the notion that TCP cannot be appropriate for use on a Local Area Network.  Originally published as M82-48 by the MITRE Corporation, Bedford Massachusetts.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc872.txt
873	A			RFCs from 1982							"Illusion of vendor support" was released in September of 1982 by M.A. Padlipsky. This memo takes issue with the claim that international standards in computer protocols presently provide a basis for low cost vendor supported protocol implementations.  Originally published as M82-49 by the MITRE Corporation, Bedford, Massachusetts.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc873.txt
874	A			RFCs from 1982							"Critique of X.25" was released in September of 1982 by M.A. Padlipsky. This RFC is an analysis of X.25 pointing out some problems in the conceptual model, particularly the conflict between the interface aspects and the end-to-end aspects.  The memo also touches on security, and implementation issues.  Originally published as M82-50 by the MITRE Corporation, Bedford, Massachusetts.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc874.txt
875	A			RFCs from 1982							"Gateways, architectures, and heffalumps" was released in September of 1982 by M.A. Padlipsky. This RFC is a discussion about the role of gateways in an internetwork, especially the problems of translating or mapping protocols between different protocol suites.  The discussion notes possible functionality mis-matches, undesirable routing "singularity points", flow control issues, and high cost of translating gateways.  Originally published as M82-51 by the MITRE Corporation, Bedford, Massachusetts.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc875.txt
876	A			RFCs from 1983							"Survey of SMTP implementations" was released in September of 1983 by D. Smallberg. This RFC is a survey of implementation status.  It does not specify an official protocol, but rather notes the status of implementation of aspects of a protocol.  It is expected that the status of the hosts reported on will change.  This information must be treated as a snapshot of the state of these implemetations.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc876.txt
877	A			RFCs from 1983							"Standard for the transmission of IP datagrams over public data networks" was released in September of 1983 by J.T. Korb. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+1356">RFC 1356</a>. This RFC specifies a standard adopted by CSNET, the VAN gateway, and other organizations for the transmission of IP datagrams over the X.25-based public data networks.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc877.txt
878	A			RFCs from 1983							"ARPANET 1822L Host Access Protocol" was released in December of 1983 by A.G. Malis. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+851">RFC 851</a>. This RFC specifies the ARPANET 1822L Host Access Protocol, which is a successor to the existing 1822 Host Access Protocol.  The 1822L procedure allows ARPANET hosts to use logical identifiers as well as 1822 physical interface identifiers to address each other.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc878.txt
879	A			RFCs from 1983							"The TCP Maximum Segment Size and Related Topics" was released in November of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC discusses the TCP Maximum Segment Size Option and related topics.  The purposes is to clarify some aspects of TCP and its interaction with IP.  This memo is a clarification to the TCP specification, and contains information that may be considered as "advice to implementers".	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc879.txt
880	A			RFCs from 1983							"Official protocols" was released in October of 1983 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+840">RFC 840</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+901">RFC 901</a>. This RFC identifies the documents specifying the official protocols used in the ARPA Internet.  Annotations identify any revisions or changes planned.  Obsoletes RFC 840.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc880.txt
881	A			RFCs from 1983							"Domain names plan and schedule" was released in November of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC outlines a plan and schedule for the implementation of domain style names throughout the DDN/ARPA Internet community.  The introduction of domain style names will impact all hosts on the DDN/ARPA Internet.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc881.txt
882	A			RFCs from 1983							"Domain names: Concepts and facilities" was released in November of 1983 by P.V. Mockapetris. This RFC introduces domain style names, their use for ARPA Internet mail and host address support, and the protocol and servers used to implement domain name facilities.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc882.txt
883	A			RFCs from 1983							"Domain names: Implementation specification" was released in November of 1983 by P.V. Mockapetris. This RFC discusses the implementation of domain name servers and resolvers, specifies the format of transactions, and discusses the use of domain names in the context of existing mail systems and other network software.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc883.txt
884	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet terminal type option" was released in December of 1983 by M. Solomon, and E. Wimmers. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+930">RFC 930</a>. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  It specifies a method for exchanging terminal type information in the Telnet protocol.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc884.txt
885	A			RFCs from 1983							"Telnet end of record option" was released in December of 1983 by J. Postel. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  It specifies a method for marking the end of records in data transmitted on Telnet connections.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc885.txt
886	A			RFCs from 1983							"Proposed standard for message header munging" was released in December of 1983 by M.T. Rose. This RFC specifies a draft standard for the ARPA Internet community.  It describes the rules to be used when transforming mail from the conventions of one message system to those of another message system.  In particular, the treatment of header fields, and recipient addresses is specified.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc886.txt
887	A			RFCs from 1983							"Resource Location Protocol" was released in December of 1983 by M. Accetta. This RFC specifies a draft standard for the ARPA Internet community.  It describes a resource location protocol for use in the ARPA Internet.  It is most useful on networks employing technologies which support some method of broadcast addressing, however it may also be used on other types of networks.  For maximum benefit, all hosts which provide significant resources or services to other hosts on the Internet should implement this protocol.  Hosts failing to implement the Resource Location Protocol risk being ignored by other hosts which are attempting to locate resources on the Internet.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc887.txt
888	A			RFCs from 1984							""STUB" Exterior Gateway Protocol" was released in January of 1984 by L. Seamonson, and E.C. Rosen. This RFC describes the Exterior Gateway Protocol used to connect Stub Gateways to an Autonomous System of core Gateways.  This document specifies the working protocol, and defines an ARPA official protocol.  All implementers of Gateways should carefully review this document.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc888.txt
889	A			RFCs from 1983							"Internet Delay Experiments" was released in December of 1983 by D.L. Mills. This memo reports on some measurements of round-trip times in the Internet and suggests some possible improvements to the TCP retransmission timeout calculation.  This memo is both a status report on the Internet and advice to TCP implementers.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc889.txt
890	A			RFCs from 1984							"Exterior Gateway Protocol implementation schedule" was released in February of 1984 by J. Postel. This memo is a policy statement on the implementation of the Exterior Gateway Protocol in the Internet.  This is an official policy statement of ICCB and DARPA.  After 1-Aug-84 there shall be no dumb gateways in the Internet.  Every gateway must be a member of some autonomous system.  Some gateway of each autonomous system must exchange routing information with some gateway of the core autonomous system using the Exterior Gateway Protocol.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc890.txt
891	A			RFCs from 1983							"DCN Local-Network Protocols" was released in December of 1983 by D.L. Mills. This RFC provides a description of the DCN protocols for maintaining connectivity, routing, and clock information in a local network.  These procedures may be of interest to the designers and implementers of other local networks.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc891.txt
892	A			RFCs from 1983							"ISO Transport Protocol specification" was released in December of 1983 by International Organization for Standardization. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+905">RFC 905</a>. This is a draft version of the transport protocol being standardized by the ISO.  This version also appeared in the ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review (V.12, N.3-4) July-October 1982.  This version is now out of date.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc892.txt
893	A			RFCs from 1984							"Trailer encapsulations" was released in April of 1984 by M.J. Karels, and S. Leffler. This RFC discusses the motivation for use of "trailer encapsulations" on local-area networks and describes the implementation of such an encapsulation on various media.  This document is for information only.  This is NOT an official protocol for the ARPA Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc893.txt

This RFC specifies a standard method of encapsulating Internet Protocol (IP) datagrams on an Ethernet.  This RFC specifies a standard protocol for the ARPA-Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc894.txt

This RFC specifies a standard method of encapsulating Internet Protocol (IP) datagrams on an Experimental Ethernet.  This RFC specifies a standard protocol for the ARPA Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc895.txt
896	A			RFCs from 1984							"Congestion Control in IP/TCP Internetworks" was released in January of 1984 by J. Nagle. This memo discusses some aspects of congestion control in IP/TCP Internetworks.  It is intended to stimulate thought and further discussion of this topic.  While some specific suggestions are made for improved congestion control implementation, this memo does not specify any standards.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc896.txt
897	A			RFCs from 1984							"Domain name system implementation schedule" was released in February of 1984 by J. Postel. This memo is a policy statement on the implementation of the Domain Style Naming System in the Internet.  This memo is a partial update of RFC 881.  The intent of this memo is to detail the schedule for the implementation for the Domain Style Naming System.  The names of hosts will be changed to domain style names.  Hosts will begin to use domain style names on 14-Mar-84, and the use of old style names will be completely phased out before 2-May-84.  This applies to both the ARPA research hosts and the DDN operational hosts.  This is an official policy statement of the ICCB and the DARPA.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc897.txt
898	A			RFCs from 1984							"Gateway special interest group meeting notes" was released in April of 1984 by R.M. Hinden, J. Postel, M. Muuss, and J.K. Reynolds. This memo is a report on the Gateway Special Interest Group Meeting that was held at ISI on 28 and 29 February 1984.  Robert Hinden of BBNCC chaired, and Jon Postel of ISI hosted the meeting.  Approximately 35 gateway designers and implementors attended.  These notes are based on the recollections of Jon Postel and Mike Muuss.  Under each topic area are Jon Postel's brief notes, and additional details from Mike Muuss.  This memo is a report on a meeting.  No conclusions, decisions, or policy statements are documented in this note.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc898.txt
899	A			RFCs from 1984							"Request For Comments summary notes: 800-899" was released in May of 1984 by J. Postel, and A. Westine. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc899.txt
900	A			RFCs from 1984							"Assigned Numbers" was released in June of 1984 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+870">RFC 870</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+923">RFC 923</a>. This RFC specifies parameter values use in the Internet family of protocols, such as network numbers, well known ports, protocol types, and version numbers.  This memo is an official status report on the protocol parameters used in the Internet protocol system.  See RFC-990 and 997.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc900.txt
901	A			RFCs from 1984							"Official ARPA-Internet protocols" was released in June of 1984 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+880">RFC 880</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+924">RFC 924</a>. This RFC identifies the documents specifying the official protocols used in the ARPA-Internet.  Annotations identify any revisions or changes planned.  This memo is an official status report on the protocols used in the DARPA research community.  See RFC-991.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc901.txt
902	A			RFCs from 1984							"ARPA Internet Protocol policy" was released in July of 1984 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. The purpose of this memo is to explain how protocol standards are adopted for the ARPA-Internet and the DARPA research community.  There are three important aspects to be discussed: the process, the authority, and the complex relationship between the DARPA community and the DDN community.  This memo is a policy statement on how protocols become official standards for the ARPA-Internet and the DARPA research community.  This is an official policy statement of the ICCB and the DARPA.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc902.txt
903	A			RFCs from 1984							"A Reverse Address Resolution Protocol" was released in June of 1984 by T. Mann, R. Finlayson, J.C. Mogul, and M. Theimer. This RFC suggests a method for workstations to dynamically find their protocol address (e.g., their Internet Address), when they know only their hardware address (e.g., their attached physical network address).  This RFC specifies a proposed protocol for the ARPA Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc903.txt
904	A			RFCs from 1984							"Exterior Gateway Protocol formal specification" was released in April of 1984 by D.L. Mills. RFC-904 is the specification of the Exterior Gateway Protocol (EGP).  This memo updates portions of RFC-888 and RFC-827.  This RFC specifies an official protocol of the DARPA community for use between gateways of different autonomous systems in the ARPA-Internet.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc904.txt
905	A			RFCs from 1984							"ISO Transport Protocol specification ISO DP 8073" was released in April of 1984 by ISO. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+892">RFC 892</a>. This is the current specification of the ISO Transport Protocol.  This document is the text of ISO/TC97/SC16/N1576 as corrected by ISO/TC97/SC16/N1695.  This is the specification currently being voted on in ISO as a Draft International Standard (DIS).  This document is distributed as an RFC for your information only, it does not specify a standard for the ARPA-Internet or DARPA research community.  Our thanks to Alex McKenzie of BBN for making this online version available.  Please note the size of this document, the file contains 258,729 characters.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc905.txt
906	A			RFCs from 1984							"Bootstrap loading using TFTP" was released in June of 1984 by R. Finlayson. It is often convenient to be able to bootstrap a computer system from a communications network.  This RFC proposes the use of the IP TFTP protocol for bootstrap loading in this case.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc906.txt
907	A			RFCs from 1984							"Host Access Protocol specification" was released in July of 1984 by Bolt Beranek and Newman Laboratories. This document specifies the Host Access Protocol (HAP).  Although HAP was originally designed as the network-access level protocol for the DARPA/DCA sponsored Wideband Packet Satellite Network, it is intended that it evolve into a standard interface SATNET and TACNET (aka MATNET) as well as the Wideband Network.  HAP is an experimental protocol, and will undergo further revision as new capabilities are added and/or different satellite networks are suported.  Implementations of HAP should be performed in coordination with satellite network development and operations personnel.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc907.txt
908	A			RFCs from 1984							"Reliable Data Protocol" was released in July of 1984 by R.M. Hinden, D. Velten, and J. Sax. The Reliable Data Protocol (RDP) is designed to provide a reliable data transport service for packet-based applications.  This RFC specifies a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet and DARPA research community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvemts.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc908.txt
909	A			RFCs from 1984							"Loader Debugger Protocol" was released in July of 1984 by W. Milliken, and C. Welles. The Loader Debugger Protocol (LDP) is an application layer protocol for loading, dumping, and debugging target machines from hosts in a network environment.  This RFC specifies a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet and DARPA research community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvemts.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc909.txt
910	A			RFCs from 1984							"Multimedia mail meeting notes" was released in August of 1984 by H.C. Forsdick. This memo is a report on a meeting about the experimental multimedia mail system (and in a sense a status report on that experiment).  The meeting was held at Bolt Beranek and Newman on 23-24 July 1984 to discuss recent progress by groups who are building multimedia mail systems and to discuss a variety of issues related to the further development of multimedia systems.  Representatives were present from BBN, ISI, SRI and Linkabit.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc910.txt
911	A			RFCs from 1984							"EGP Gateway under Berkeley UNIX 4.2" was released in August of 1984 by P. Kirton. This memo describes an implementation of the Exterior Gateway Protocol (EGP) (in that sense it is a status report).  The memo also discusses some possible extentions and some design issues (in that sense it is an invitation for further discussion).	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc911.txt
912	A			RFCs from 1984							"Authentication service" was released in September of 1984 by M. St. Johns. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+931">RFC 931</a>. This memo describes a proposed authentication protocol for verifying the identity of a user of a TCP connection.  Given a TCP port number pair, it returns a character string which identifies the owner of that connection on the server's system.  Suggested uses include automatic identification and verification of a user during an FTP session, additional verification of a TAC dial up user, and access verification for a generalized network file server.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc912.txt
913	A			RFCs from 1984							"Simple File Transfer Protocol" was released in September of 1984 by M. Lottor. This memo describes a proposed Simple File Transfer Protocol (SFTP).  It fills the need of people wanting a protocol that is more useful than TFTP but easier to implement (and less powerful) than FTP.  SFTP supports user access control, file transfers, directory listing, directory changing, file renaming and deleting.  Discussion of this proposal is encouraged, and suggestions for improvements may be sent to the author.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc913.txt
914	A			RFCs from 1984							"Thinwire protocol for connecting personal computers to the Internet" was released in September of 1984 by T.M. Conte, G. Delp, and D.J. Farber. This RFC focuses discussion on the particular problems in the ARPA-Internet of low speed network interconnection with personal computers, and possible methods of solution.  None of the proposed solutions in this document are intended as standards for the ARPA-Internet.  Rather, it is hoped that a general consensus will emerge as to the appropriate solution to the problems, leading eventually to the adoption of standards.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc914.txt
915	A			RFCs from 1984							"Network mail path service" was released in December of 1984 by R. Nedved, and M.A. Elvy. This RFC proposed a new service for the ARPA-Internet community and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.  The network mail path service fills the current need of people to determine mailbox addresses for hosts that are not part of the ARPA-Internet but can be reached by one or more relay hosts that have Unix to Unix Copy (UUCP) mail, CSNET mail, MAILNET mail, BITNET mail, etc.  Anyone can use the service if they have TCP/TELENET to one of the hosts with a mail path server.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc915.txt
916	A			RFCs from 1984							"Reliable Asynchronous Transfer Protocol (RATP)" was released in October of 1984 by G.G. Finn. This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.  This paper proposes and specifies a protocol which allows two programs to reliably communicate over a communication link.  It ensures that the data entering one end of the link if received arrives at the other end intact and unaltered.  The protocol, named RATP, is designed to operate over a full duplex point-to-point connection.  It contains some features which tailor it to the RS-232 links now in common use.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc916.txt
917	A			RFCs from 1984							"Internet subnets" was released in October of 1984 by J.C. Mogul. This memo discusses subnets and proposes procedures for the use of subnets, including approaches to solving the problems that arise, particularly that of routing.  A subnet of an Internet network is a logically visible sub-section of a single Internet network.  For administrative or technical reasons, many organizations have chosen to divide one Internet network into several subnets, instead of acquiring a set of Internet network numbers.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc917.txt
918	A			RFCs from 1984							"Post Office Protocol" was released in October of 1984 by J.K. Reynolds. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+937">RFC 937</a>. This RFC suggests a simple method for workstations to dynamically access mail from a mailbox server.  The intent of the Post Office Protocol (POP) is to allow a user's workstation to access mail from a mailbox server.  It is expected that mail will be posted from the workstation to the mailbox server via the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP).  This RFC specifies a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvement.  The status of this protocol is experimental, and this protocol is dependent upon TCP.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc918.txt
919	A			RFCs from 1984							"Broadcasting Internet Datagrams" was released in October of 1984 by J.C. Mogul. This RFC proposes simple rules for broadcasting Internet datagrams on local networks that support broadcast, for addressing broadcasts, and for how gateways should handle them.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc919.txt
920	A			RFCs from 1984							"Domain requirements" was released in October of 1984 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. This memo states the requirements on establishing a Domain, and introduces the limited set of top level domains.  This memo is a policy statement on the requirements of establishing a new domain in the ARPA-Internet and the DARPA research community.  This is an official policy statement of the IAB and the DARPA.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc920.txt

This is an official policy statement of the IAB and the DARPA.  The intent of this memo is to detail the schedule for the implementation for the Domain Style Naming System.  The explanation of how this system works is to be found in the references.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc921.txt

We propose simple rules for broadcasting Internet datagrams on local networks that support broadcast, for addressing broadcasts, and for how gateways should handle them.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc922.txt
923	A			RFCs from 1984							"Assigned numbers" was released in October of 1984 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+900">RFC 900</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+943">RFC 943</a>. This RFC documents the currently assigned values from several series of numbers used in network protocol implementations.  This edition of Assigned Numbers obsoletes RFC-900 and earlier editions.  This memo is an official status report on the numbers used in protocols in the ARPA-Internet community.  See RFC-990, and 997.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc923.txt
924	A			RFCs from 1984							"Official ARPA-Internet protocols for connecting personal computers to the Internet" was released in October of 1984 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+901">RFC 901</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+944">RFC 944</a>. This RFC identifies the documents specifying the official protocols used in the Internet.  This edition of Official ARPA-Internet Protocols obsoletes RFC-900 and earlier editions.  This memo is an official status report on the protocols used in the ARPA-Internet community.  See RFC-991.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc924.txt
925	A			RFCs from 1984							"Multi-LAN address resolution" was released in October of 1984 by J. Postel. The problem of treating a set of local area networks (LANs) as one Internet network has generated some interest and concern.  It is inappropriate to give each LAN within an site a distinct Internet network number.  It is desirable to hide the details of the interconnections between the LANs within an site from people, gateways, and hosts outside the site.  The question arises on how to best do this, and even how to do it at all.  In RFC-917 Jeffery Mogul makes a case for the use of "explicit subnets" in a multi-LAN environment.  The explicit subnet scheme is a call to recursively apply the mechanisms the Internet uses to manage networks to the problem of managing LANs within one network.  In this note I urge another approach: the use of "transparent subnets" supported by a multi-LAN extension of the Address Resolution Protocol.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc925.txt
926	A			RFCs from 1984							"Protocol for providing the connectionless mode network services" was released in December of 1984 by International Organization for Standardization. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+994">RFC 994</a>. This note is the draft ISO protocol roughly similar to the DOD Internet Protocol.  This document has been prepared by retyping the text of ISO DIS 8473 of May 1984, which is currently undergoing voting within ISO as a Draft International Standard (DIS).  This document is distributred as an RFC for information only.  It does not specify a standard for the ARPA-Internet.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc926.txt
927	A			RFCs from 1984							"TACACS user identification Telnet option" was released in December of 1984 by B.A. Anderson. The following is the description of a TELNET option designed to facilitate double login avoidance.  It is intended primarily for TAC connections to target hosts on behalf of TAC users, but it can be used between any two consenting hosts.  For example, all hosts at one site (e.g., BBN) can use this option to avoid double login when TELNETing to one another.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc927.txt
928	A			RFCs from 1984							"Introduction to proposed DoD standard H-FP" was released in December of 1984 by M.A. Padlipsky. The broad outline of the Host-Front End Protocol introduced here and described in RFC-929 is the result of the deliberations of a number of experienced H-FP designers, who sat as a committee of the DoD Protocol Standards Technical Panel.  It is the intent of the designers that the protocol be subjected to multiple test implementations and probable iteration before being agreed upon as any sort of "standard".  Therefore, the first order of business is to declare that THIS IS A PROPOSAL, NOT A FINAL STANDARD, and the second order of business is to request that any readers of these documents who are able to do test implementations (a) do so and (b) coordinate their efforts with the author.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc928.txt
929	A			RFCs from 1984							"Proposed Host-Front End Protocol" was released in December of 1984 by J. Lilienkamp, M.A. Padlipsky, and R. Mandell. The Host-Front End Protocol introduced in RFC-928 is described in detail in this memo.  The first order of business is to declare that THIS IS A PROPOSAL, NOT A FINAL STANDARD, and the second order of business is to request that any readers of these documents who are able to do test implementations (a) do so and (b) coordinate their efforts with the author.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc929.txt
930	A			RFCs from 1985							"Telnet terminal type option" was released in January of 1985 by M. Solomon, and E. Wimmers. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+884">RFC 884</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+1091">RFC 1091</a>. This RFC specifies a standard for the ARPA Internet community.  Hosts on the ARPA Internet that exchange terminal type information within the Telnet protocol are expected to adopt and implement this standard.  This standard supersedes RFC-884.  The only change is to specify that the TERMINAL-TYPE IS sub-negotiation should be sent only in response to the TERMINAL-TYPE SEND sub-negotiation.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc930.txt
931	A			RFCs from 1985							"Authentication server" was released in January of 1985 by M. St. Johns. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+912">RFC 912</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+1413">RFC 1413</a>. This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.  This is the second draft of this proposal (superseding RFC-912) and incorporates a more formal description of the syntax for the request and response dialog, as well as a change to specify the type of user identification returned.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc931.txt
932	A			RFCs from 1985							"Subnetwork addressing scheme" was released in January of 1985 by D.D. Clark. This RFC proposes an alternative addressing scheme for subnets which, in most cases, requires no modification to host software whatsoever.  The drawbacks of this scheme are that the total number of subnets in any one network are limited, and that modification is required to all gateways.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc932.txt
933	A			RFCs from 1985							"Output marking Telnet option" was released in January of 1985 by S. Silverman. This proposed option would allow a Server-Telnet to send a banner to a User-Telnet so that this banner would be displayed on the workstation screen independently of the application software running in the Server-Telnet.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc933.txt
934	A			RFCs from 1985							"Proposed standard for message encapsulation" was released in January of 1985 by E.A. Stefferud, and M.T. Rose. This memo concerns itself with message forwarding.  Forwarding can be thought of as encapsulating one or more messages inside another.  Although this is useful for transfer of past correspondence to new recipients, without a decapsulation process (which this memo terms "bursting"), the forwarded messages are of little use to the recipients because they can not be distributed, forwarded, replied-to, or otherwise processed as separate individual messages.  In order to burst a message it is necessary to know how the component messages were encapsulated in the draft.  At present there is no unambiguous standard for interest group digests.  This RFC proposes a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc934.txt
935	A			RFCs from 1985							"Reliable link layer protocols" was released in January of 1985 by J.G. Robinson. This RFC discusses protocols proposed recently in RFCs 914 and 916, and suggests a proposed protocol that could meet the same needs addressed in those memos.  The stated need is reliable communication between two programs over a full-duplex, point-to-point communication link, and in particular the RFCs address the need for such communication over an asynchronous link at relatively low speeds.  The suggested protocol uses the methods of existing national and international data link layer standards.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc935.txt
936	A			RFCs from 1985							"Another Internet subnet addressing scheme" was released in February of 1985 by M.J. Karels. There have been several proposals for schemes to allow the use of a single Internet network number to refer to a collection of physical networks under common administration which are reachable from the rest of the Internet by a common route.  Such schemes allow a simplified view of an otherwise complicated topology from hosts and gateways outside of this collection.  They allow the complexity of the number and type of these networks, and routing to them, to be localized.  Additions and changes in configuration thus cause no detectable change, and no interruption of service, due to slow propagation of routing and other information outside of the local environment.  These schemes also simplify the administration of the network, as changes do not require allocation of new network numbers for each new cable installed.  This proposal discusses an alternative scheme, one that has been in use at the University of California, Berkeley since April 1984.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc936.txt
937	A			RFCs from 1985							"Post Office Protocol: Version 2" was released in February of 1985 by J. Postel, M. Butler, D. Chase, J.K. Reynolds, and J. Goldberger. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+918">RFC 918</a>. This RFC suggests a simple method for workstations to dynamically access mail from a mailbox server.  This RFC specifies a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvement.  This memo is a revision of RFC-918.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc937.txt
938	A			RFCs from 1985							"Internet Reliable Transaction Protocol functional and interface specification" was released in February of 1985 by T. Miller. This RFC is being distributed to members of the DARPA research community in order to solicit their reactions to the proposals contained in it.  While the issues discussed may not be directly relevant to the research problems of the DARPA community, they may be interesting to a number of researchers and implementors.  This RFC suggests a proposed protocol for the ARPA-Internet community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc938.txt
939	A			RFCs from 1985							"Executive summary of the NRC report on transport protocols for Department of Defense data networks" was released in February of 1985 by National Research Council. This RFC reproduces the material from the "front pages" of the National Research Council report resulting from a study of the DOD Internet Protocol (IP) and Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) in comparison with the ISO Internet Protocol (ISO-IP) and Transport Protocol level 4 (TP-4).  The point of this RFC is to make the text of the Executive Summary widely available in a timely way.  The order of presentation has been altered, and the pagination changed.  This RFC is distributed for information only.  This RFC does not establish any policy for the DARPA research community or the DDN operational community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc939.txt
940	A			RFCs from 1985							"Toward an Internet standard scheme for subnetting" was released in April of 1985 by Gateway Algorithms and Data Structures Task Force. Several sites now contain a complex of local links connected to the Internet via a gateway.  The details of the internal connectivity are of little interest to the rest of the Internet.  One way of organizing these local complexes of links is to use the same strategy as the Internet uses to organize networks, that is, to declare each link to be an entity (like a network) and to interconnect the links with devices that perform routing functions (like gateways).  This general scheme is called subnetting, the individual links are called subnets, and the connecting devices are called subgateways (or bridges, or gateways).  This RFC discusses standardizing the protocol used in subnetted environments in the ARPA-Internet.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc940.txt
941	A			RFCs from 1985							"Addendum to the network service definition covering network layer addressing" was released in April of 1985 by International Organization for Standardization. This Addendum to the Network Service Definition Standard, ISO 8348, defines the abstract syntax and semantics of the Network Address (Network Service Access Point Address).  The Network Address defined in this Addendum is the address that appears in the primitives of the connection-mode Network Service as the calling address, called address, and responding address parameters, and in the primitives of the connectionless-mode Network Service as the source address and destination address parameters.  This document is distributed as an RFC for information only.  It does not specify a standard for the ARPA-Internet.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc941.txt
942	A			RFCs from 1985							"Transport protocols for Department of Defense data networks" was released in February of 1985 by National Research Council. 943	A			RFCs from 1985							"Assigned numbers" was released in April of 1985 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+923">RFC 923</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+960">RFC 960</a>. This Network Working Group Request for Comments documents the currently assigned values from several series of numbers used in network protocol implementations.  This RFC will be updated periodically, and in any case current information can be obtained from Joyce Reynolds.  The assignment of numbers is also handled by Joyce.  If you are developing a protocol or application that will require the use of a link, socket, port, protocol, network number, etc., please contact Joyce to receive a number assignment.  This memo is an official status report on the numbers used in protocols in the ARPA-Internet community.  See RFC-990 and 997.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc943.txt
944	A			RFCs from 1985							"Official ARPA-Internet protocols" was released in April of 1985 by J. Postel, and J.K. Reynolds.
