This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2161.txt
2162	A			RFCs from 1998							"MaXIM-11 - Mapping between X.400 / Internet mail and  Mail-11 mail" was released in January of 1998 by C. Allocchio. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1405">RFC 1405</a>. The standard referred shortly into this document as "X.400" relates to the ISO/IEC 10021 - CCITT 1984, 1988 and 1992 X.400 Series Recommendations covering the Message Oriented Text Interchange Service (MOTIS).  This document covers the Inter Personal Messaging System (IPMS) only.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2162.txt
2163	A			RFCs from 1998							"Using the Internet DNS to Distribute MIXER Conformant Global Address Mapping (MCGAM)" was released in January of 1998 by C. Allocchio. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1664">RFC 1664</a>. This memo is the complete technical specification to store in the Internet Domain Name System (DNS) the mapping information (MCGAM) needed by MIXER conformant e-mail gateways and other tools to map RFC822 domain names into X.400 O/R names and vice versa. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2163.txt
2164	A			RFCs from 1998							"Use of an X.500/LDAP directory to support MIXER address mapping" was released in January of 1998 by S. Kille. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1838">RFC 1838</a>. This specification defines how to represent and maintain these mappings (MIXER Conformant Global Address Mappings of MCGAMs) in an X.500 or LDAP directory. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2164.txt
2165	A			RFCs from 1997							"Service Location Protocol" was released in June of 1997 by S. Kaplan, C. Perkins, E. Guttman, and J. Veizades. The Service Location Protocol provides a scalable framework for the discovery and selection of network services.  Using this protocol, computers using the Internet no longer need so much static configuration of network services for network based applications.  This is especially important as computers become more portable, and users less tolerant or able to fulfill the demands of network system administration. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2165.txt
2166	A			RFCs from 1997							"APPN Implementer's Workshop Closed Pages Document DLSw v2.0 Enhancements" was released in June of 1997 by P. Brittain, and D. Bryant. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1714">RFC 1714</a>. This memo describes Version 1.5 of the client/server interaction of RWhois.  RWhois provides a distributed system for the discovery, retrieval, and maintenance of directory information.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  This memo does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2167.txt
2168	A			RFCs from 1997							"Resolution of Uniform Resource Identifiers using the Domain Name System" was released in June of 1997 by M. Mealling, and R. Daniel. The requirements document for URN resolution systems defines the concept of a "resolver discovery service".  This document describes the first, experimental, RDS.  It is implemented by a new DNS Resource Record, NAPTR (Naming Authority PoinTeR), that provides rules for mapping parts of URIs to domain names.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2168.txt

This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.  This memo does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.  Discussion and suggestions for improvement are requested.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2169.txt

2178	A			RFCs from 1997							"OSPF Version 2" was released in July of 1997 by J. Moy. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1583">RFC 1583</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2328">RFC 2328</a>. This memo documents version 2 of the OSPF protocol. OSPF is a link-state routing protocol. It is designed to be run internal to a single Autonomous System. Each OSPF router maintains an identical database describing the Autonomous System's topology. From this database, a routing table is calculated by constructing a shortest-path tree.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2178.txt

2217	A			RFCs from 1997							"Telnet Com Port Control Option" was released in October of 1997 by G. Clark. 2218	A			RFCs from 1997							"A Common Schema for the Internet White Pages Service" was released in October of 1997 by B. Jennings, and T. Genovese. 2219	A			RFCs from 1997							"Use of DNS Aliases for Network Services" was released in October of 1997 by M. Hamilton, and R. Wright. It has become a common practice to use symbolic names (usually CNAMEs) in the Domain Name Service (DNS - [RFC-1034, RFC-1035]) to refer to network services such as anonymous FTP [RFC-959] servers, Gopher [RFC- 1436] servers, and most notably World-Wide Web HTTP [RFC-1945] servers.  This is desirable for a number of reasons.  It provides a way of moving services from one machine to another transparently, and a mechanism by which people or agents may programmatically discover that an organization runs, say, a World-Wide Web server.  Although this approach has been almost universally adopted, there is no standards document or similar specification for these commonly used names.  This document seeks to rectify this situation by gathering together the extant 'folklore' on naming conventions, and proposes a mechanism for accommodating new protocols.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2219.txt
2220	A			RFCs from 1997							"The Application/MARC Content-type" was released in October of 1997 by R. Guenther. This memorandum provides a mechanism for representing objects which are files of Machine-Readable Cataloging records (MARC).  The MARC formats are standards for the representation and communication of bibliographic and related information.  A MARC record contains metadata for an information resource following MARC format specifications.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2220.txt
2221	A			RFCs from 1997							"IMAP4 Login Referrals" was released in October of 1997 by M. Gahrns. When dealing with large amounts of users and many IMAP4 [RFC-2060] servers, it is often necessary to move users from one IMAP4 server to another.  Login referrals allow clients to transparently connect to an alternate IMAP4 server, if their home IMAP4 server has changed. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2221.txt
2222	A			RFCs from 1997							"Simple Authentication and Security Layer (SASL)" was released in October of 1997 by J. Myers. This document describes a method for adding authentication support to connection-based protocols. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2222.txt
2223	A			RFCs from 1997							"Instructions to RFC Authors" was released in October of 1997 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. This Request for Comments (RFC) provides information about the preparation of RFCs, and certain policies relating to the publication of RFCs.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  This memo does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2223.txt
2224	A			RFCs from 1997							"NFS URL Scheme" was released in October of 1997 by B. Callaghan. A new URL scheme, 'nfs' is defined.  It is used to refer to files and directories on NFS servers using the general URL syntax defined in RFC 1738, "Uniform Resource Locators (URL)".  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2224.txt

[STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2225.txt

This mechanism is intended to be used only with the Secure DNS.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2230.txt

It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2184">RFC 2184</a>. This memo defines extensions to the RFC 2045 media type and RFC 2183 disposition parameter value mechanisms. 2234	A			RFCs from 1997							"Augmented BNF for Syntax Specifications: ABNF" was released in November of 1997 by P. Overell, and D. Crocker. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4234">RFC 4234</a>. In the early days of the Arpanet, each specification contained its own definition of ABNF.  This included the email specifications, RFC733 and then RFC822 which have come to be the common citations for defining ABNF.  The current document separates out that definition, to permit selective reference.  Predictably, it also provides some modifications and enhancements. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2234.txt

It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2038">RFC 2038</a>. This memo describes a packetization scheme for MPEG video and audio streams. [STANDARDS-TRACK] The purpose of this document is to express the general Internet community's expectations of Computer Security Incident Response Teams (CSIRTs).  It is not possible to define a set of requirements that would be appropriate for all teams, but it is possible and helpful to list and describe the general set of topics and issues which are of concern and interest to constituent communities.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2250.txt

2262	A			RFCs from 1998							"Message Processing and Dispatching for the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)" was released in January of 1998 by B. Wijnen, R. Presuhn, D. Harrington, and J. Case. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2272">RFC 2272</a>. This document describes the Message Processing and Dispatching for SNMP messages within the SNMP architecture [RFC2261].  It defines the procedures for dispatching potentially multiple versions of SNMP messages to the proper SNMP Message Processing Models, and for dispatching PDUs to SNMP applications.  This document also describes one Message Processing Model - the SNMPv3 Message Processing Model. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2262.txt
2263	A			RFCs from 1998							"SNMPv3 Applications" was released in January of 1998 by D. Levi, P. Meyer, and B. Stewart. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2273">RFC 2273</a>. This memo describes five types of SNMP applications which make use of an SNMP engine as described in [RFC2261].  The types of application described are Command Generators, Command Responders, Notification Originators, Notification Receivers, and Proxy Forwarders.  This memo also defines MIB modules for specifying targets of management operations, for notification filtering, and for proxy forwarding. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2263.txt
2264	A			RFCs from 1998							"User-based Security Model (USM) for version 3 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv3)" was released in January of 1998 by U. Blumenthal, and B. Wijnen. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2274">RFC 2274</a>. This document describes the User-based Security Model (USM) for SNMP version 3 for use in the SNMP architecture [RFC2261].  It defines the Elements of Procedure for providing SNMP message level security.  This document also includes a MIB for remotely monitoring/managing the configuration parameters for this Security Model. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2264.txt

It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2827">RFC 2827</a>. This paper discusses a simple, effective, and straightforward method for using ingress traffic filtering to prohibit DoS attacks which use forged IP addresses to be propagated from 'behind' an Internet Service Provider's (ISP) aggregation point.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2267.txt

2270	A			RFCs from 1998							"Using a Dedicated AS for Sites  Homed to a Single Provider" was released in January of 1998 by E. Chen, T. Bates, J. Stewart, and R. Chandra. With the increased growth of the Internet, the number of customers using BGP4 has grown significantly.  RFC1930 outlines a set of guidelines for when one needs and should use an AS.  However, the customer and service provider (ISP) are left with a problem as a result of this in that while there is no need for an allocated AS under the guidelines, certain conditions make the use of BGP4 a very pragmatic and perhaps only way to connect a customer homed to a single ISP.  This paper proposes a solution to this problem in line with recommendations set forth in RFC1930.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2270.txt

2277	A			RFCs from 1998							"IETF Policy on Character Sets and Languages" was released in January of 1998 by H. Alvestrand. This document is the current policies being applied by the Internet Engineering Steering Group (IESG) towards the standardization efforts in the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) in order to help Internet protocols fulfill these requirements.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2277.txt
2278	A			RFCs from 1998							"IANA Charset Registration Procedures" was released in January of 1998 by J. Postel, and N. Freed. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2978">RFC 2978</a>. MIME [RFC-2045, RFC-2046, RFC-2047, RFC-2184] and various other modern Internet protocols are capable of using many different charsets.  This in turn means that the ability to label different charsets is essential.  This registration procedure exists solely to associate a specific name or names with a given charset and to give an indication of whether or not a given charset can be used in MIME text objects.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2278.txt
2279	A			RFCs from 1998							"UTF-8, a transformation format of ISO 10646" was released in January of 1998 by F. Yergeau. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2044">RFC 2044</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3629">RFC 3629</a>. UTF-8, the object of this memo, has the characteristic of preserving the full US-ASCII range, providing compatibility with file systems, parsers and other software that rely on US-ASCII values but are transparent to other values.  This memo updates and replaces RFC 2044, in particular addressing the question of versions of the relevant standards. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2279.txt
2280	A			RFCs from 1998							"Routing Policy Specification Language (RPSL)" was released in January of 1998 by D. Karrenberg, C. Villamizar, T. Bates, M. Terpstra, E. Gerich, C. Alaettinoglu, and D. Meyer. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2622">RFC 2622</a>. This memo is the reference document for the Routing Policy Specification Language (RPSL).  RPSL allows a network operator to be able to specify routing policies at various levels in the Internet hierarchy; for example at the Autonomous System (AS) level.  At the same time, policies can be specified with sufficient detail in RPSL so that low level router configurations can be generated from them.  RPSL is extensible; new routing protocols and new protocol features can be introduced at any time. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2280.txt
2281	A			RFCs from 1998							"Cisco Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP)" was released in March of 1998 by P. Morton, T. Li, B. Cole, and D. Li. The memo specifies the Hot Standby Router Protocol (HSRP).  The goal of the protocol is to allow hosts to appear to use a single router and to maintain connectivity even if the actual first hop router they are using fails.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2281.txt
2282	A			RFCs from 1998							"IAB and IESG Selection, Confirmation, and Recall Process: Operation of the Nominating and Recall Committees" was released in February of 1998 by J. Galvin. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2027">RFC 2027</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2727">RFC 2727</a>. The process by which the members of the IAB and IESG are selected, confirmed, and recalled is specified.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2282.txt
2283	A			RFCs from 1998							"Multiprotocol Extensions for BGP-4" was released in February of 1998 by Y. Rekhter, T. Bates, R. Chandra, and D. Katz. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2858">RFC 2858</a>. This document defines extensions to BGP-4 to enable it to carry routing information for multiple Network Layer protocols (e.g., IPv6, IPX, etc...).  The extensions are backward compatible - a router that supports the extensions can interoperate with a router that doesn't support the extensions. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2283.txt
2284	A			RFCs from 1998							"PPP Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP)" was released in March of 1998 by J. Vollbrecht, and L. Blunk. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3748">RFC 3748</a>. The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links.  PPP also defines an extensible Link Control Protocol, which allows negotiation of an Authentication Protocol for authenticating its peer before allowing Network Layer protocols to transmit over the link.  This document defines the PPP Extensible Authentication Protocol. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2284.txt
2285	A			RFCs from 1998							"Benchmarking Terminology for LAN Switching Devices" was released in February of 1998 by R. Mandeville. This document is intended to provide terminology for the benchmarking of local area network (LAN) switching devices.  It extends the terminology already defined for benchmarking network interconnect devices in RFCs 1242 and 1944 to switching devices.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2285.txt
2286	A			RFCs from 1998							"Test Cases for HMAC-RIPEMD160 and HMAC-RIPEMD128" was released in February of 1998 by J. Kapp. This document provides two sets of test cases for HMAC-RIPEMD160 and HMAC-RIPEMD128.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2286.txt
2287	A			RFCs from 1998							"Definitions of System-Level Managed Objects for Applications" was released in February of 1998 by J. Saperia, and C. Krupczak. This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the Internet community.  In particular, it describes a basic set of managed objects for fault, configuration and performance management of applications from a systems perspective. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2287.txt
2288	A			RFCs from 1998							"Using Existing Bibliographic Identifiers as Uniform Resource Names" was released in February of 1998 by C. Preston, C. Lynch, and R. Daniel. This document discusses how three major bibliographic identifiers (the ISBN, ISSN and SICI) can be supported within the URN framework and the currently proposed syntax for URNs.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2288.txt
2289	A			RFCs from 1998							"A One-Time Password System" was released in February of 1998 by N. Haller, M. Straw, P. Nesser, and C. Metz. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1938">RFC 1938</a>. This document describes a one-time password authentication system (OTP).  The system provides authentication for system access (login) and other applications requiring authentication that is secure against passive attacks based on replaying captured reusable passwords. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2289.txt
2290	A			RFCs from 1998							"Mobile-IPv4 Configuration Option for PPP IPCP" was released in February of 1998 by S. Glass, and J. Solomon. Mobile IP [RFC 2002] defines media-independent procedures by which a Mobile Node can maintain existing transport and application-layer connections despite changing its point-of-attachment to the Internet and without changing its IP address.  PPP [RFC 1661] provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol packets over point-to-point links.  As currently specified, Mobile IP Foreign Agents which support Mobile Node connections via PPP can do so only by first assigning unique addresses to those Mobile Nodes, defeating one of the primary advantages of Foreign Agents.  This documents corrects this problem by defining the Mobile-IPv4 Configuration Option to the Internet Protocol Control Protocol (IPCP) [RFC 1332].  Using this option, two peers can communicate their support for Mobile IP during the IPCP phase of PPP.  Familiarity with Mobile IP [RFC 2002], IPCP [RFC 1332], and PPP [RFC 1661] is assumed. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2290.txt
2291	A			RFCs from 1998							"Requirements for a Distributed Authoring and Versioning Protocol for the World Wide Web" was released in February of 1998 by D. Durand, F. Vitali, J. Slein, and E. Whitehead. This document presents a list of features in the form of requirements for a Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning protocol which, if implemented, would improve the efficiency of common remote editing operations, provide a locking mechanism to prevent overwrite conflicts, improve link management support between non-HTML data types, provide a simple attribute-value metadata facility, provide for the creation and reading of container data types, and integrate versioning into the WWW.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2291.txt
2292	A			RFCs from 1998							"Advanced Sockets API for IPv6" was released in February of 1998 by M. Thomas, and W. Stevens. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3542">RFC 3542</a>. The current document defines some the "advanced" features of the sockets API that are required for applications to take advantage of additional features of IPv6.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2292.txt
2293	A			RFCs from 1998							"Representing Tables and Subtrees in the X.500 Directory" was released in March of 1998 by S. Kille. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1837">RFC 1837</a>. This document defines techniques for representing two types of information mapping in the OSI Directory: Mapping from a key to a value (or set of values), as might be done in a table lookup, and mapping from a distinguished name to an associated value (or values), where the values are not defined by the owner of the entry.  This is achieved by use of a directory subtree. [STANDARDS-TRCK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2293.txt
2294	A			RFCs from 1998							"Representing the O/R Address hierarchy in the X.500 Directory Information Tree" was released in March of 1998 by S. Kille. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1836">RFC 1836</a>. This document defines a representation of the O/R Address hierarchy in the Directory Information Tree. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2294.txt
2295	A			RFCs from 1998							"Transparent Content Negotiation in HTTP" was released in March of 1998 by A. Mutz, and K. Holtman. HTTP allows web site authors to put multiple versions of the same information under a single URL.  Transparent content negotiation is an extensible negotiation mechanism, layered on top of HTTP, for automatically selecting the best version when the URL is accessed.  This enables the smooth deployment of new web data formats and markup tags.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.  Discussion and suggestions for improvement are requested.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2295.txt
2296	A			RFCs from 1998							"HTTP Remote Variant Selection Algorithm -- RVSA/1.0" was released in March of 1998 by A. Mutz, and K. Holtman. HTTP allows web site authors to put multiple versions of the same information under a single URL.  Transparent content negotiation is a mechanism for automatically selecting the best version when the URL is accessed.  A remote variant selection algorithm can be used to speed up the transparent negotiation process.  This document defines the remote variant selection algorithm with the version number 1.0.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.  Discussion and suggestions for improvement are requested.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2296.txt
2297	A			RFCs from 1998							"Ipsilon's General Switch Management Protocol Specification Version 2.0" was released in March of 1998 by G. Minshall, F. Ching Liaw, E. Hoffman, P. Newman, T. Lyon, W. Edwards, and R. Hinden. This memo specifies enhancements to the General Switch Management Protocol (GSMP) [RFC1987].  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2297.txt

This memo defines a MIME content-type that may be used by a mail user agent (UA) or electronic mail gateway to report the disposition of a message after it has been sucessfully delivered to a recipient. 2300	A			RFCs from 1998							"Internet Official Protocol Standards" was released in May of 1998 by J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2200">RFC 2200</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2400">RFC 2400</a>. A discussion of the standardization process and the RFC document series is presented first, followed by an explanation of the terms.  Sections 6.2 - 6.10 contain the lists of protocols in each stage of standardization.  Finally are pointers to references and contacts for further information. 2307	A			RFCs from 1998							"An Approach for Using LDAP as a Network Information Service" was released in March of 1998 by L. Howard. This document describes an experimental mechanism for mapping entities related to TCP/IP and the UNIX system into X.500 entries so that they may be resolved with the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol [RFC2251]. 2308	A			RFCs from 1998							"Negative Caching of DNS Queries (DNS NCACHE)" was released in March of 1998 by M. Andrews. RFC1034 provided a description of how to cache negative responses.  It however had a fundamental flaw in that it did not allow a name server to hand out those cached responses to other resolvers, thereby greatly reducing the effect of the caching.  This document addresses issues raise in the light of experience and replaces RFC1034 Section 4.3.4. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2308.txt
2309	A			RFCs from 1998							"Recommendations on Queue Management and Congestion Avoidance in the Internet" was released in April of 1998 by S. Shenker, D. Clark, G. Minshall, S. Deering, V. Jacobson, J. Crowcroft, D. Estrin, L. Zhang, B. Braden, J. Wroclawski, L. Peterson, B. Davie, S. Floyd, K. Ramakrishnan, and C. Partridge. This memo presents two recommendations to the Internet community concerning measures to improve and preserve Internet performance.  It presents a strong recommendation for testing, standardization, and widespread deployment of active queue management in routers, to improve the performance of today's Internet.  It also urges a concerted effort of research, measurement, and ultimate deployment of router mechanisms to protect the Internet from flows that are not sufficiently responsive to congestion notification.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2309.txt

Discussion and suggestions for improvement are requested.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2310.txt

We identified the core security components of the architecture, and specified several documents that need to be written. 2332	A			RFCs from 1998							"NBMA Next Hop Resolution Protocol (NHRP)" was released in April of 1998 by N. Doraswamy, B. Cole, D. Piscitello, D. Katz, and J. Luciani. This document describes the NBMA Next Hop Resolution Protocol (NHRP).  NHRP can be used by a source station (host or router) connected to a Non-Broadcast, Multi-Access (NBMA) subnetwork to determine the internetworking layer address and NBMA subnetwork addresses of the "NBMA next hop" towards a destination station. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2332.txt
2333	A			RFCs from 1998							"NHRP Protocol Applicability Statement" was released in April of 1998 by D. Cansever. As required by the Routing Protocol Criteria [RFC 1264], this memo discusses the applicability of the Next Hop Resolution Protocol (NHRP) in routing of IP datagrams over Non-Broadcast Multiple Access (NBMA) networks, such as ATM, SMDS and X.25. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2333.txt
2334	A			RFCs from 1998							"Server Cache Synchronization Protocol (SCSP)" was released in April of 1998 by G. Armitage, N. Doraswamy, J. Halpern, and J. Luciani. This document describes the Server Cache Synchronization Protocol (SCSP) and is written in terms of SCSP's use within Non Broadcast Multiple Access (NBMA) networks; although, a somewhat straight forward usage is applicable to BMA networks. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2334.txt
2335	A			RFCs from 1998							"A Distributed NHRP Service Using SCSP" was released in April of 1998 by J. Luciani. This document describes a method for distributing an NHRP service within a LIS. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2335.txt
2336	A			RFCs from 1998							"Classical IP to NHRP Transition" was released in July of 1998 by J. Luciani. This document describes methods and procedures for the graceful transition from an ATMARP LIS to an NHRP LIS network model over ATM.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2336.txt
2337	A			RFCs from 1998							"Intra-LIS IP multicast among routers over ATM using Sparse Mode PIM" was released in April of 1998 by Y. Rekhter, D. Meyer, and D. Farinacci. This document describes how intra-LIS IP multicast can be efficiently supported among routers over ATM without using the Multicast Address Resolution Server (MARS).  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.  Discussion and suggestions for improvement are requested.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2337.txt
2338	A			RFCs from 1998							"Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol" was released in April of 1998 by P. Hunt, D. Weaver, R. Hinden, A. Lindem, D. Whipple, S. Knight, D. Mitzel, M. Shand, and P. Higginson. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3768">RFC 3768</a>. This memo defines the Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP).  VRRP specifies an election protocol that dynamically assigns responsibility for a virtual router to one of the VRRP routers on a LAN. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2338.txt

This document describes the Layer Two Forwarding protocol (L2F) which permits the tunneling of the link layer (i.e., HDLC, async HDLC, or SLIP frames) of higher level protocols.  This memo describes a historic protocol for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2341.txt

2344	A			RFCs from 1998							"Reverse Tunneling for Mobile IP" was released in May of 1998 by G. Montenegro. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3024">RFC 3024</a>. 2345	A			RFCs from 1998							"Domain Names and Company Name Retrieval" was released in May of 1998 by J. Klensin, G. Oglesby, and T. Wolf. This document proposes a company name to URL mapping service based on the oldest and least complex of Internet directory protocols, whois, in order to explore whether an extremely simple and widely-deployed protocol can succeed where more complex and powerful options have failed or been excessively delayed.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.  Discussion and suggestions for improvement are requested.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2345.txt
2346	A			RFCs from 1998							"Making Postscript and PDF International" was released in May of 1998 by J. Palme. Certain text formats, for example Postscript (MIME-Type: application/postscript; file extension .ps) and Portable Document Format (MIME-Type: application/pdf; file extension .pdf) specify exactly the page layout of the printed document.  The commonly used paper format is different in North America and the rest of the world.  North America uses the 'Letter' format, while the rest of the world mostly uses the ISO-standard 'A4' format.  This means that documents formatted on one continent may not be easily printable on another continent.  This memo gives advice on how to produce documents which are equally well printable with the Letter and the A4 formats.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2346.txt
2347	A			RFCs from 1998							"TFTP Option Extension" was released in May of 1998 by A. Harkin, and G. Malkin. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1782">RFC 1782</a>. The Trivial File Transfer Protocol is a simple, lock-step, file transfer protocol which allows a client to get or put a file onto a remote host.  This document describes a simple extension to TFTP to allow option negotiation prior to the file transfer. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2347.txt
2348	A			RFCs from 1998							"TFTP Blocksize Option" was released in May of 1998 by A. Harkin, and G. Malkin. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1783">RFC 1783</a>. The Trivial File Transfer Protocol is a simple, lock-step, file transfer protocol which allows a client to get or put a file onto a remote host.  This document describes a TFTP option which allows the client and server to negotiate a blocksize more applicable to the network medium. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2348.txt
2349	A			RFCs from 1998							"TFTP Timeout Interval and Transfer Size Options" was released in May of 1998 by A. Harkin, and G. Malkin. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1784">RFC 1784</a>. The Trivial File Transfer Protocol is a simple, lock-step, file transfer protocol which allows a client to get or put a file onto a remote host.  This document describes two TFTP options. 2356	A			RFCs from 1998							"Sun's SKIP Firewall Traversal for Mobile IP" was released in June of 1998 by V. Gupta, and G. Montenegro. The Mobile IP specification establishes the mechanisms that enable a mobile host to maintain and use the same IP address as it changes its point of attachment to the network.  The mechanisms described in this document allow a mobile node out on a public sector of the internet to negotiate access past a SKIP firewall, and construct a secure channel into its home network.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  This memo does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2356.txt

2365	A			RFCs from 1998							"Administratively Scoped IP Multicast" was released in July of 1998 by D. Meyer. This document defines the "administratively scoped IPv4 multicast space" to be the range 239.0.0.0 to 239.255.255.255.  In addition, it describes a simple set of semantics for the implementation of Administratively Scoped IP Multicast.  Finally, it provides a mapping between the IPv6 multicast address classes [RFC1884] and IPv4 multicast address classes.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2365.txt

In particular, it describes managed objects for IP hosts and routers that use a Multicast Address Resolution Server (MARS) to support IP multicast over ATM, as described in 'Support for Multicast over UNI 3.0/3.1 based ATM Networks'. 2369	A			RFCs from 1998							"The Use of URLs as Meta-Syntax for Core Mail List Commands and their Transport through Message Header Fields" was released in July of 1998 by G. Neufeld, and J. Baer. The mailing list command specification header fields are a set of structured fields to be added to email messages sent by email distribution lists.  By including these header fields, list servers can make it possible for mail clients to provide automated tools for users to perform list functions.  This could take the form of a menu item, push button, or other user interface element.  The intent is to simplify the user experience, providing a common interface to the often cryptic and varied mailing list manager commands. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2369.txt

2371	A			RFCs from 1998							"Transaction Internet Protocol Version 3.0" was released in July of 1998 by K. Evans, J. Klein, and J. Lyon. In many applications where different nodes cooperate on some work, there is a need to guarantee that the work happens atomically.  That is, each node must reach the same conclusion as to whether the work is to be completed, even in the face of failures.  This document proposes a simple, easily-implemented protocol for achieving this end. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2371.txt

2393	A			RFCs from 1998							"IP Payload Compression Protocol (IPComp)" was released in December of 1998 by A. Shacham, R. Monsour, M. Thomas, and R. Pereira. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3173">RFC 3173</a>. This document describes a protocol intended to provide lossless compression for Internet Protocol datagrams in an Internet environment. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2393.txt
2394	A			RFCs from 1998							"IP Payload Compression Using DEFLATE" was released in December of 1998 by R. Pereira. This document describes a compression method based on the DEFLATE compression algorithm.  This document defines the application of the DEFLATE algorithm to the IP Payload Compression Protocol.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2394.txt
2395	A			RFCs from 1998							"IP Payload Compression Using LZS" was released in December of 1998 by R. Friend, and R. Monsour. This document describes a compression method based on the LZS compression algorithm.  This document defines the application of the LZS algorithm to the IP Payload Compression Protocol.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2395.txt
2396	A			RFCs from 1998							"Uniform Resource Identifiers (URI): Generic Syntax" was released in August of 1998 by L. Masinter, T. Berners-Lee, and R. Fielding. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3986">RFC 3986</a>. This document defines a grammar that is a superset of all valid URI, such that an implementation can parse the common components of a URI reference without knowing the scheme-specific requirements of every possible identifier type. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt
2397	A			RFCs from 1998							"The "data" URL scheme" was released in August of 1998 by L. Masinter. A new URL scheme, "data", is defined.  It allows inclusion of small data items as "immediate" data, as if it had been included externally. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2397.txt
2398	A			RFCs from 1998							"Some Testing Tools for TCP Implementors" was released in August of 1998 by C. Schmechel, and S. Parker. This document lists only tools which can evaluate one or more TCP implementations, or which can privde some specific results which describe or evaluate the TCP being tested.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.  It does not specify an Internet standard of any kind.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2398.txt
2399	A			RFCs from 1999							"Request for Comments Summary" was released in January of 1999 by A. Ramos. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2399.txt
2400	A			RFCs from 1998							"Internet Official Protocol Standards" was released in September of 1998 by J. Reynolds, and J. Postel. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2300">RFC 2300</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2500">RFC 2500</a>. This memo describes the state of standardization of protocols used in the Internet as determined by the Internet Architecture Board (IAB).  This memo is an Internet Standard. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2400.txt
2401	A			RFCs from 1998							"Security Architecture for the Internet Protocol" was released in November of 1998 by R. Atkinson, and S. Kent. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1825">RFC 1825</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4301">RFC 4301</a>. This memo specifies the base architecture for IPsec compliant systems. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2401.txt
2402	A			RFCs from 1998							"IP Authentication Header" was released in November of 1998 by R. Atkinson, and S. Kent. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1826">RFC 1826</a>. The IP Authentication Header (AH) is used to provide connectionless integrity and data origin authentication for IP datagrams (hereafter referred to as just "authentication"), and to provide protection against replays. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2402.txt
2403	A			RFCs from 1998							"The Use of HMAC-MD5-96 within ESP and AH" was released in November of 1998 by R. Glenn, and C. Madson. This memo describes the use of the HMAC algorithm in conjunction with the MD5 algorithm as an authentication mechanism within the revised IPSEC Encapsulating Security Payload and the revised IPSEC Authentication Header. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2403.txt
2404	A			RFCs from 1998							"The Use of HMAC-SHA-1-96 within ESP and AH" was released in November of 1998 by R. Glenn, and C. Madson. This memo describes the use of the HMAC algorithm in conjunction with the SHA-1 algorithm as an authentication mechanism within the revised IPSEC Encapsulating Security Payload and the revised IPSEC Authentication Header. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2404.txt
2405	A			RFCs from 1998							"The ESP DES-CBC Cipher Algorithm With Explicit IV" was released in November of 1998 by N. Doraswamy, and C. Madson. This document describes the use of the DES Cipher algorithm in Cipher Block Chaining Mode, with an explicit IV, as a confidentiality mechanism within the context of the IPSec Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP). [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2405.txt
2406	A			RFCs from 1998							"IP Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP)" was released in November of 1998 by R. Atkinson, and S. Kent. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1827">RFC 1827</a>. The Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP) header is designed to provide a mix of security services in IPv4 and IPv6. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2406.txt
2407	A			RFCs from 1998							"The Internet IP Security Domain of Interpretation for ISAKMP" was released in November of 1998 by D. Piper. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4306">RFC 4306</a>. This document defines the Internet IP Security DOI (IPSEC DOI), which instantiates ISAKMP for use with IP when IP uses ISAKMP to negotiate security associations. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2407.txt
2408	A			RFCs from 1998							"Internet Security Association and Key Management Protocol (ISAKMP)" was released in November of 1998 by J. Turner, M. Schneider, M. Schertler, and D. Maughan. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4306">RFC 4306</a>. This memo describes a protocol utilizing security concepts necessary for establishing Security Associations (SA) and cryptographic keys in an Internet environment. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2408.txt
2409	A			RFCs from 1998							"The Internet Key Exchange (IKE)" was released in November of 1998 by D. Carrel, and D. Harkins. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4306">RFC 4306</a>. This memo describes a hybrid protocol.  The purpose is to negotiate, and provide authenticated keying material for, security associations in a protected manner. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2409.txt
2410	A			RFCs from 1998							"The NULL Encryption Algorithm and Its Use With IPsec" was released in November of 1998 by S. Kent, and R. Glenn. This memo defines the NULL encryption algorithm and its use with the IPsec Encapsulating Security Payload (ESP). [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2410.txt
2411	A			RFCs from 1998							"IP Security Document Roadmap" was released in November of 1998 by N. Doraswamy, R. Glenn, and R. Thayer. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+6071">RFC 6071</a>. This document is intended to provide guidelines for the development of collateral specifications describing the use of new encryption and authentication algorithms with the ESP protocol, described in and new authentication algorithms used with the AH protocol.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2411.txt
2412	A			RFCs from 1998							"The OAKLEY Key Determination Protocol" was released in November of 1998 by H. Orman. This document describes a protocol, named OAKLEY, by which two authenticated parties can agree on secure and secret keying material.  The basic mechanism is the Diffie-Hellman key exchange algorithm.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2412.txt
2413	A			RFCs from 1998							"Dublin Core Metadata for Resource Discovery" was released in September of 1998 by M. Wolf, J. Kunze, S. Weibel, and C. Lagoze. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5013">RFC 5013</a>. This is the first of a set of Informational RFCs describing the Dublin Core.  Its purpose is to introduce the Dublin Core and to describe the consensus reached on the semantics of each of the 15 elements.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2413.txt
2414	A			RFCs from 1998							"Increasing TCP's Initial Window" was released in September of 1998 by M. Allman, S. Floyd, and C. Partridge. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3390">RFC 3390</a>. This document specifies an increase in the permitted initial window for TCP from one segment to roughly 4K bytes.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2414.txt
2415	A			RFCs from 1998							"Simulation Studies of Increased Initial TCP Window Size" was released in September of 1998 by K. Nichols, and K. Poduri. This document covers some simulation studies of the effects of increasing the initial window size of TCP.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2415.txt
2416	A			RFCs from 1998							"When TCP Starts Up With Four Packets Into Only Three Buffers" was released in September of 1998 by T. Shepard, and C. Partridge. This memo is to document a simple experiment.  The experiment showed that in the case of a TCP receiver behind a 9600 bps modem link at the edge of a fast Internet where there are only 3 buffers before the modem (and the fourth packet of a four-packet start will surely be dropped), no significant degradation in performance is experienced by a TCP sending with a four-packet start when compared with a normal slow start (which starts with just one packet).  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2416.txt
2417	A			RFCs from 1998							"Definitions of Managed Objects for Multicast over UNI 3.0/3.1 based ATM Networks" was released in September of 1998 by M. Greene, and C. Chung. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2366">RFC 2366</a>. This memo specifies a MIB module in a manner that is both compliant to the SNMPv2 SMI, and semantically identical to the peer SNMPv1 definitions. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2417.txt
2418	A			RFCs from 1998							"IETF Working Group Guidelines and Procedures" was released in September of 1998 by S. Bradner. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1603">RFC 1603</a>. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2418.txt

2433	A			RFCs from 1998							"Microsoft PPP CHAP Extensions" was released in October of 1998 by G. Zorn, and S. Cobb. PPP defines an extensible Link Control Protocol and a family of Network Control Protocols (NCPs) for establishing and configuring different network-layer protocols.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2433.txt

This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2438.txt
2439	A			RFCs from 1998							"BGP Route Flap Damping" was released in November of 1998 by C. Villamizar, R. Govindan, and R. Chandra. A usage of the BGP routing protocol is described which is capable of reducing the routing traffic passed on to routing peers and therefore the load on these peers without adversely affecting route convergence time for relatively stable routes. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2439.txt

This memo provides information for the Internet community	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2442.txt
2443	A			RFCs from 1998							"A Distributed MARS Service Using SCSP" was released in November of 1998 by A. Gallo, and J. Luciani. This document describes a method for distributing a MARS service within a LIS.  This method uses the Server Cache Synchronization Protocol (SCSP) to synchronize the MARS Server databases within a LIS.  When SCSP is used to synchronize the caches of MARS Servers in a LIS, the LIS defines the boundary of an SCSP Server Group (SG). [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2443.txt
2444	A			RFCs from 1998							"The One-Time-Password SASL Mechanism" was released in October of 1998 by C. Newman. OTP provides a useful authentication mechanism for situations where there is limited client or server trust.  Currently, OTP is added to protocols in an ad-hoc fashion with heuristic parsing.  This specification defines an OTP SASL mechanism so it can be easily and formally integrated into many application protocols. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2444.txt
2445	A			RFCs from 1998							"Internet Calendaring and Scheduling Core Object Specification (iCalendar)" was released in November of 1998 by D. Stenerson, and F. Dawson. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5545">RFC 5545</a>. This memo has been defined to provide the definition of a common format for openly exchanging calendaring and scheduling information across the Internet. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2445.txt
2446	A			RFCs from 1998							"iCalendar Transport-Independent Interoperability Protocol (iTIP) Scheduling Events, BusyTime, To-dos and Journal Entries" was released in November of 1998 by R. Hopson, S. Mansour, F. Dawson, and S. Silverberg. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5546">RFC 5546</a>. This document specifies how calendaring systems use iCalendar objects to interoperate with other calendar systems.  It does so in a general way so as to allow multiple methods of communication between systems. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2446.txt

2448	A			RFCs from 1998							"AT&T's Error Resilient Video Transmission Technique" was released in November of 1998 by B. Haskell, G. Cash, and M. Civanlar. It not only clearly states how to use certain cipher algorithms, but also how to use all CBC-mode cipher algorithms. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2451.txt

2455	A			RFCs from 1998							"Definitions of Managed Objects for APPN" was released in November of 1998 by B. Moore, and B. Clouston. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2155">RFC 2155</a>. This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the Internet community.  In particular, it defines objects for monitoring and controlling network devices with APPN (Advanced Peer-to-Peer Networking) capabilities.  This memo identifies managed objects for the APPN protocol. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2455.txt
2456	A			RFCs from 1998							"Definitions of Managed Objects for APPN TRAPS" was released in November of 1998 by B. Moore, and B. Clouston. This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the Internet community.  In particular, it defines objects for receiving notifications from network devices with APPN (Advanced Peer-to-Peer Network) and DLUR (Dependent LU Requester) capabilities.  This memo identifies notifications for the APPN and DLUR architecture. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2456.txt

2468	A			RFCs from 1998							"I REMEMBER IANA" was released in October of 1998 by V. Cerf. A long time ago, in a network, far far away, a great adventure took place!.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2468.txt
2469	A			RFCs from 1998							"A Caution On The Canonical Ordering Of Link-Layer Addresses" was released in December of 1998 by C. Burton, and T. Narten. Protocols such as ARP and Neighbor Discovery have data fields that contain link-layer addresses.  In order to interoperate properly, a sender setting such a field must insure that the receiver extracts those bits and interprets them correctly.  In most cases, such fields must be in "canonical form".  Unfortunately, not all LAN adaptors are consistent in their use of canonical form, and implementations may need to explicitly bit swap individual bytes in order to obtain the correct format.  This document provides information to implementors to help them avoid the pitfall of using non-canonical forms when canonical forms are required.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2469.txt
2470	A			RFCs from 1998							"Transmission of IPv6 Packets over Token Ring Networks" was released in December of 1998 by S. Thomas, T. Narten, and M. Crawford. This memo specifies the MTU and frame format for transmission of IPv6 packets on Token Ring networks. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2470.txt

It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1897">RFC 1897</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3701">RFC 3701</a>. This document describes an allocation plan for IPv6 addresses to be used in testing IPv6 prototype software.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2471.txt

2477	A			RFCs from 1999							"Criteria for Evaluating Roaming Protocols" was released in January of 1999 by G. Zorn, and B. Aboba. This document describes requirements for the provisioning of "roaming capability" for dialup Internet users. "Roaming capability" is defined as the ability to use multiple Internet service providers (ISPs), while maintaining a formal, customer-vendor relationship with only one.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2477.txt

2479	A			RFCs from 1998							"Independent Data Unit Protection Generic Security Service Application Program Interface (IDUP-GSS-API)" was released in December of 1998 by C. Adams. The IDUP-GSS-API extends the GSS-API for applications requiring protection of a generic data unit (such as a file or message) in a way which is independent of the protection of any other data unit and independent of any concurrent contact with designated "receivers" of the data unit.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2479.txt

2483	A			RFCs from 1999							"URI Resolution Services Necessary for URN Resolution" was released in January of 1999 by M. Mealling, and R. Daniel. Retrieving the resource identified by a Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) is only one of the operations that can be performed on a URI.  One might also ask for and get a list of other identifiers that are aliases for the original URI or a bibliographic description of the resource the URI denotes, for example.  This applies to both Uniform Resource Names (URNs) and Uniform Resource Locators (URLs).  Uniform Resource Characteristics (URCs) are discussed in this document but only as descriptions of resources rather than identifiers.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2483.txt
2484	A			RFCs from 1999							"PPP LCP Internationalization Configuration Option" was released in January of 1999 by G. Zorn. The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links.  PPP also defines an extensible Link Control Protocol (LCP), which allows negotiation of an Authentication Protocol for authenticating its peer before allowing Network Layer protocols to transmit over the link. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2484.txt

2488	A			RFCs from 1999							"Enhancing TCP Over Satellite Channels using Standard Mechanisms" was released in January of 1999 by M. Allman, D. Glover, and L. Sanchez. The Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) provides reliable delivery of data across any network path, including network paths containing satellite channels.  While TCP works over satellite channels there are several IETF standardized mechanisms that enable TCP to more effectively utilize the available capacity of the network path.  This document outlines some of these TCP mitigations.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2488.txt

2492	A			RFCs from 1999							"IPv6 over ATM Networks" was released in January of 1999 by P. Schulter, G. Armitage, and M. Jork. This document is a companion to the ION working group's architecture document, "IPv6 over Non Broadcast Multiple Access (NBMA) networks".  It provides specific details on how to apply the IPv6 over NBMA architecture to ATM networks.  This architecture allows conventional host-side operation of the IPv6 Neighbor Discovery protocol, while also supporting the establishment of 'shortcut' ATM forwarding paths (when using SVCs).  Operation over administratively configured Point to Point PVCs is also supported. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2492.txt

2515	A			RFCs from 1999							"Definitions of Managed Objects for ATM Management" was released in February of 1999 by K. Tesink, and Ed. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1695">RFC 1695</a>. This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the Internet community.  In particular, it describes objects used for managing ATM-based interfaces, devices, networks and services. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2515.txt
2516	A			RFCs from 1999							"A Method for Transmitting PPP Over Ethernet (PPPoE)" was released in February of 1999 by K. Lidl, D. Simone, D. Carrel, J. Evarts, R. Wheeler, and L. Mamakos. This document describes how to build PPP sessions and encapsulate PPP packets over Ethernet.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2516.txt
2517	A			RFCs from 1999							"Building Directories from DNS: Experiences from WWWSeeker" was released in February of 1999 by R. Huber, and R. Moats. This memo discusses lessons that were learned during InterNIC Directory and Database Services' development and operation of WWWSeeker, an application that finds a web site given information about the name and location of an organization.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2517.txt
2518	A			RFCs from 1999							"HTTP Extensions for Distributed Authoring -- WEBDAV" was released in February of 1999 by D. Jensen, A. Faizi, Y. Goland, E. Whitehead, and S. Carter. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4918">RFC 4918</a>. This document specifies a set of methods, headers, and content-types ancillary to HTTP/1.1 for the management of resource properties, creation and management of resource collections, namespace manipulation, and resource locking (collision avoidance). [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2518.txt
2519	A			RFCs from 1999							"A Framework for Inter-Domain Route Aggregation" was released in February of 1999 by E. Chen, and J. Stewart. This document presents a framework for inter-domain route aggregation and shows an example router configuration which 'implements' this framework.  This memo provides information for the Internet community	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2519.txt
2520	A			RFCs from 1999							"NHRP with Mobile NHCs" was released in February of 1999 by D. Horton, N. Doraswamy, H. Suzuki, and J. Luciani. is document describes an extension to NHRP which would allow Mobile NHCs to perform a registration with and attach to an NHS in their home LIS in an authenticated manner.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2520.txt

This document specifies ICMP messages for indicating failures when using IP Security Protocols (AH and ESP).  This document defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2521.txt

2523	A			RFCs from 1999							"Photuris: Extended Schemes and Attributes" was released in March of 1999 by W. Simpson, and P. Karn. Photuris is a session-key management protocol.  Extensible Exchange- Schemes are provided to enable future implementation changes without affecting the basic protocol.  This document defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2523.txt

2526	A			RFCs from 1999							"Reserved IPv6 Subnet Anycast Addresses" was released in March of 1999 by S. Deering, and D. Johnson. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2526.txt
2527	A			RFCs from 1999							"Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Certificate Policy and Certification Practices Framework" was released in March of 1999 by S. Chokhani, and W. Ford. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3647">RFC 3647</a>. This document presents a framework to assist the writers of certificate policies or certification practice statements for certification authorities and public key infrastructures.  In particular, the framework provides a comprehensive list of topics that potentially (at the writer's discretion) need to be covered in a certificate policy definition or a certification practice statement.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2527.txt

Housley, and W. Polk. This specification contains guidance on the use of the Internet Public Key Infrastructure certificates to convey Key Exchange Algorithm (KEA) keys.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2528.txt
2529	A			RFCs from 1999							"Transmission of IPv6 over IPv4 Domains without Explicit Tunnels" was released in March of 1999 by B. Carpenter, and C. Jung. This memo specifies the frame format for transmission of IPv6 (IPV6) packets and the method of forming IPv6 link-local addresses over IPv4 domains.  It also specifies the content of the Source/Target Link-layer Address option used in the Router Solicitation, Router Advertisement, Neighbor Solicitation, and Neighbor Advertisement and Redirect messages, when those messages are transmitted on an IPv4 multicast network. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2529.txt

2531	A			RFCs from 1999							"Content Feature Schema for Internet Fax" was released in March of 1999 by L. McIntyre, and G. Klyne. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2879">RFC 2879</a>. A standard method for storing RSA keys and and RSA/MD5 based signatures in the Domain Name System is described which utilizes DNS KEY and SIG resource records. 2538	A			RFCs from 1999							"Storing Certificates in the Domain Name System (DNS)" was released in March of 1999 by O. Gudmundsson, and D. Eastlake 3rd. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4398">RFC 4398</a>. Cryptographic public key are frequently published and their authenticity demonstrated by certificates.  A CERT resource record (RR) is defined so that such certificates and related certificate revocation lists can be stored in the Domain Name System (DNS). A standard format is defined for representing detached DNS information.  This is anticipated to be of use for storing information retrieved from the Domain Name System (DNS), including security information, in archival contexts or contexts not connected to the Internet.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2540.txt

The Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) is an application-layer control (signaling) protocol for creating, modifying and terminating sessions with one or more participants. 2544	A			RFCs from 1999							"Benchmarking Methodology for Network Interconnect Devices" was released in March of 1999 by J. McQuaid, and S. Bradner. 2545	A			RFCs from 1999							"Use of BGP-4 Multiprotocol Extensions for IPv6 Inter-Domain Routing" was released in March of 1999 by F. Dupont, and P. Marques. BGP-4 Multiprotocol Extensions (BGP-MP) defines the format of two BGP attributes (MP_REACH_NLRI and MP_UNREACH_NLRI) that can be used to announce and withdraw the announcement of reachability information.  This document defines how compliant systems should make use of those attributes for the purpose of conveying IPv6 routing information. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2545.txt
2546	A			RFCs from 1999							"6Bone Routing Practice" was released in March of 1999 by B. Buclin, and A. Durand. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2772">RFC 2772</a>. This memo identifies guidelines on how 6Bone sites might operate, so that the 6Bone can remain a quality experimentation environment and to avoid pathological situations that have been encountered in the past.  It defines the 'best current practice' acceptable in the 6Bone for the configuration of both Interior Gateway Protocols and Exterior Gateway Protocols.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2546.txt

This memo documents the process used by the Roman community for the standardization of protocols and procedures. 2552	A			RFCs from 1999							"Architecture for the Information Brokerage in the ACTS Project GAIA" was released in April of 1999 by C. Clissmann, M. Bessonov, and M. Blinov. 2553	A			RFCs from 1999							"Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6" was released in March of 1999 by R. Gilligan, J. Bound, W. Stevens, and S. Thomson. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2133">RFC 2133</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3493">RFC 3493</a>. TCP/IP applications written using the sockets API have in the past enjoyed a high degree of portability and we would like the same portability with IPv6 applications.  But changes are required to the sockets API to support IPv6 and this memo describes these changes.  These include a new socket address structure to carry IPv6 addresses, new address conversion functions, and some new socket options.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2553.txt
2554	A			RFCs from 1999							"SMTP Service Extension for Authentication" was released in March of 1999 by J. Myers. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4954">RFC 4954</a>. This document defines an SMTP service extension [ESMTP] whereby an SMTP client may indicate an authentication mechanism to the server, perform an authentication protocol exchange, and optionally negotiate a security layer for subsequent protocol interactions. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2554.txt
2555	A			RFCs from 1999							"30 Years of RFCs" was released in April of 1999 by et al., and RFC Editor. The rest of this document contains a brief recollection from the present RFC Editor Joyce K.  Reynolds, followed by recollections from three pioneers: Steve Crocker who wrote RFC 1, Vint Cerf whose long-range vision continues to guide us, and Jake Feinler who played a key role in the middle years of the RFC series.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2555.txt
2556	A			RFCs from 1999							"OSI connectionless transport services on top of UDP Applicability Statement for Historic Status" was released in March of 1999 by S. Bradner. RFC 1240, "OSI connectionless transport services on top of UDP", was published as a Proposed Standard in June 1991 but at this time there do not seem to be any implementations which follow RFC 1240.  In addition there is a growing concern over using UDP-based transport protocols in environments where congestion is a possibility This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2556.txt
2557	A			RFCs from 1999							"MIME Encapsulation of Aggregate Documents, such as HTML (MHTML)" was released in March of 1999 by A. Hopmann, J. Palme, and N. Shelness. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2110">RFC 2110</a>. This document a) defines the use of a MIME multipart/related structure to aggregate a text/html root resource and the subsidiary resources it references, and b) specifies a MIME content-header (Content-Location) that allow URIs in a multipart/related text/html root body part to reference subsidiary resources in other body parts of the same multipart/related structure. 2558	A			RFCs from 1999							"Definitions of Managed Objects for the SONET/SDH Interface Type" was released in March of 1999 by K. Tesink. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1595">RFC 1595</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3592">RFC 3592</a>. This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in TCP/IP-based internets.  In particular, it defines objects for managing Synchronous Optical Network/Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SONET/SDH) interfaces.  This document is a companion to the documents that define Managed Objects for the DS1/E1/DS2/E2 and DS3/E3 Interface Types. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2558.txt

Myers. This document specifies a protocol useful in determining the current status of a digital certificate without requiring CRLs. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2560.txt

2564	A			RFCs from 1999							"Application Management MIB" was released in May of 1999 by R. Presuhn, J. Saperia, C. Kalbfleisch, and C. Krupczak. This memo defines a standards track portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the Internet Community.  In particular, it defines objects used for the management of applications. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2564.txt
2565	A			RFCs from 1999							"Internet Printing Protocol/1.0: Encoding and Transport" was released in April of 1999 by R. Turner, P. Moore, S. Butler, and R. Herriot. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2910">RFC 2910</a>. This document defines the rules for encoding IPP operations and IPP attributes into a new Internet mime media type called "application/ipp".  This document also defines the rules for transporting over HTTP a message body whose Content-Type is "application/ipp".  This document defines an Experimental protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2565.txt
2566	A			RFCs from 1999							"Internet Printing Protocol/1.0: Model and Semantics" was released in April of 1999 by P. Powell, R. Herriot, T. Hastings, R. deBry, and S. Isaacson. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2911">RFC 2911</a>. This document describes a simplified model consisting of abstract objects, their attributes, and their operations that is independent of encoding and transport.  This document also addresses security, internationalization, and directory issues.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2566.txt
2567	A			RFCs from 1999							"Design Goals for an Internet Printing Protocol" was released in April of 1999 by F. Wright. This document takes a broad look at distributed printing functionality, and it enumerates real-life scenarios that help to clarify the features that need to be included in a printing protocol for the Internet.  It identifies requirements for three types of users: end users, operators, and administrators.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2567.txt
2568	A			RFCs from 1999							"Rationale for the Structure of the Model and Protocol for the Internet Printing Protocol" was released in April of 1999 by S. Zilles. This document describes IPP from a high level view, defines a roadmap for the various documents that form the suite of IPP specifications, and gives background and rationale for the IETF working group's major decisions.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2568.txt
2569	A			RFCs from 1999							"Mapping between LPD and IPP Protocols" was released in April of 1999 by J. Martin, N. Jacobs, T. Hastings, and R. Herriot. This document is one of a set of documents, which together describe all aspects of a new Internet Printing Protocol (IPP).  One of the purposes of this document is to compare the functionality of the two protocols.  Another purpose is to facilitate implementation of gateways between LPD and IPP.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2569.txt
2570	A			RFCs from 1999							"Introduction to Version 3 of the Internet-standard Network Management Framework" was released in April of 1999 by D. Partain, R. Mundy, J. Case, and B. Stewart. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3410">RFC 3410</a>. The purpose of this document is to provide an overview of the third version of the Internet-standard Management Framework, termed the SNMP version 3 Framework (SNMPv3).  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2570.txt
2571	A			RFCs from 1999							"An Architecture for Describing SNMP Management Frameworks" was released in April of 1999 by R. Presuhn, B. Wijnen, and D. Harrington. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2271">RFC 2271</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3411">RFC 3411</a>. This document describes an architecture for describing SNMP Management Frameworks. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2571.txt
2572	A			RFCs from 1999							"Message Processing and Dispatching for the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)" was released in April of 1999 by B. Wijnen, R. Presuhn, D. Harrington, and J. Case. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2272">RFC 2272</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3412">RFC 3412</a>. This document describes the Message Processing and Dispatching for SNMP messages within the SNMP architecture.  It defines the procedures for dispatching potentially multiple versions of SNMP messages to the proper SNMP Message Processing Models, and for dispatching PDUs to SNMP applications.  This document also describes one Message Processing Model - the SNMPv3 Message Processing Model. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2572.txt
2573	A			RFCs from 1999							"SNMP Applications" was released in April of 1999 by D. Levi, P. Meyer, and B. Stewart. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2273">RFC 2273</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3413">RFC 3413</a>. This memo describes five types of SNMP applications which make use of an SNMP engine.  This memo also defines MIB modules for specifying targets of management operations, for notification filtering, and for proxy fowarding. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2573.txt
2574	A			RFCs from 1999							"User-based Security Model (USM) for version 3 of the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMPv3)" was released in April of 1999 by U. Blumenthal, and B. Wijnen. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2274">RFC 2274</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3414">RFC 3414</a>. This document describes the User-based Security Model (USM) for SNMP version 3 for use in the SNMP architecture.  It defines the Elements of Procedure for providing SNMP message level security.  This document also includes a MIB for remotely monitoring/managing the configuration parameters for this Security Model. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2574.txt
2575	A			RFCs from 1999							"View-based Access Control Model (VACM) for the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)" was released in April of 1999 by R. Presuhn, B. Wijnen, and K. McCloghrie. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2275">RFC 2275</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3415">RFC 3415</a>. This document describes the View-based Access Control Model for use in the SNMP architecture (RFC2571).  It defines the Elements of Procedure for controlling access to management information.  This document also includes a MIB for remotely managing the configuration parameters for the View-based Access Control Model. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2575.txt

2581	A			RFCs from 1999							"TCP Congestion Control" was released in April of 1999 by M. Allman, V. Paxson, and W. Stevens. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2001">RFC 2001</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5681">RFC 5681</a>. This document defines TCP's four intertwined congestion control algorithms: slow start, congestion avoidance, fast retransmit, and fast recovery.  In addition, the document specifies how TCP should begin transmission after a relatively long idle period, as well as discussing various acknowledgment generation methods. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2581.txt

We also explain why some firewall mechanisms - such as SOCKS - that were designed specifically for unicast traffic, are less appropriate for multicast.
