2608	A			RFCs from 1999							"Service Location Protocol, Version 2" was released in June of 1999 by M. Day, C. Perkins, E. Guttman, and J. Veizades. The Service Location Protocol provides a scalable framework for the discovery and selection of network services.  Using this protocol, computers using the Internet need little or no static configuration of network services for network based applications.  This is especially important as computers become more portable, and users less tolerant or able to fulfill the demands of network system administration. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2608.txt

2622	A			RFCs from 1999							"Routing Policy Specification Language (RPSL)" was released in June of 1999 by D. Karrenberg, C. Villamizar, T. Bates, C. Alaettinoglu, E. Gerich, D. Kessens, M. Terpstra, and D. Meyer. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2280">RFC 2280</a>. RPSL allows a network operator to be able to specify routing policies at various levels in the Internet hierarchy; for example at the Autonomous System (AS) level.  At the same time, policies can be specified with sufficient detail in RPSL so that low level router configurations can be generated from them.  RPSL is extensible; new routing protocols and new protocol features can be introduced at any time. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2622.txt

2625	A			RFCs from 1999							"IP and ARP over Fibre Channel" was released in June of 1999 by M. Rajagopal, R. Bhagwat, and W. Rickard. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4338">RFC 4338</a>. The purpose of this document is to specify a way of encapsulating IP and Address Resolution Protocol(ARP) over Fibre Channel and also to describe a mechanism(s) for IP address resolution. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2625.txt
2626	A			RFCs from 1999							"The Internet and the Millennium Problem (Year 2000)" was released in June of 1999 by P. Nesser II. The Year 2000 Working Group (WG) has conducted an investigation into the millennium problem as it regards Internet related protocols.  This investigation only targeted the protocols as documented in the Request For Comments Series (RFCs).  This investigation discovered little reason for concern with regards to the functionality of the protocols.  A few minor cases of older implementations still using two digit years (ala RFC 850) were discovered, but almost all Internet protocols were given a clean bill of health.  Several cases of "period" problems were discovered, where a time field would "roll over" as the size of field was reached.  In particular, there are several protocols, which have 32 bit, signed integer representations of the number of seconds since January 1, 1970 which will turn negative at Tue Jan 19 03:14:07 GMT 2038.  Areas whose protocols will be effected by such problems have been notified so that new revisions will remove this limitation.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2626.txt
2627	A			RFCs from 1999							"Key Management for Multicast: Issues and Architectures" was released in June of 1999 by D. Wallner, E. Harder, and R. Agee. This report contains a discussion of the difficult problem of key management for multicast communication sessions.  It focuses on two main areas of concern with respect to key management, which are, initializing the multicast group with a common net key and rekeying the multicast group.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2627.txt
2628	A			RFCs from 1999							"Simple Cryptographic Program Interface (Crypto API)" was released in June of 1999 by V. Smyslov. This document describes a simple Application Program Interface to cryptographic functions.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2628.txt

This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2629.txt

2632	A			RFCs from 1999							"S/MIME Version 3 Certificate Handling" was released in June of 1999 by B. Ramsdell. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3850">RFC 3850</a>. S/MIME (Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions), provides a method to send and receive secure MIME messages.  Before using a public key to provide security services, the S/MIME agent MUST certify that the public key is valid.  S/MIME agents MUST use PKIX certificates to validate public keys as described in the Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure (PKIX) Certificate and CRL Profile. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2632.txt

This document describes a protocol for adding cryptographic signature and encryption services to MIME data. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2633.txt
2634	A			RFCs from 1999							"Enhanced Security Services for S/MIME" was released in June of 1999 by P. Hoffman. This document describes four optional security service extensions for S/MIME. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2634.txt
2635	A			RFCs from 1999							"DON'T SPEW A Set of Guidelines for Mass Unsolicited Mailings and Postings (spam*)" was released in June of 1999 by A. Lunde, and S. Hambridge. This document explains why mass unsolicited electronic mail messages are harmful in the Internetworking community.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2635.txt
2636	A			RFCs from 1999							"Wireless Device Configuration (OTASP/OTAPA) via ACAP" was released in July of 1999 by R. Gellens. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2604">RFC 2604</a>. This paper describes a viable and attractive means to provide OTASP/OTAPA via IS-707, using the ACAP protocol.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2636.txt
2637	A			RFCs from 1999							"Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol (PPTP)" was released in July of 1999 by K. Hamzeh, G. Zorn, J. Taarud, W. Verthein, G. Pall, and W. Little. This document specifies a protocol which allows the Point to Point Protocol (PPP) to be tunneled through an IP network.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2637.txt
2638	A			RFCs from 1999							"A Two-bit Differentiated Services Architecture for the Internet" was released in July of 1999 by K. Nichols, L. Zhang, and V. Jacobson. This document presents a differentiated services architecture for the internet.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2638.txt
2639	A			RFCs from 1999							"Internet Printing Protocol/1.0: Implementer's Guide" was released in July of 1999 by C. Manros, and T. Hastings. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3196">RFC 3196</a>. This document contains information that supplements the IPP Model and Semantics and the IPP Transport and Encoding documents.  It is intended to help implementers understand IPP/1.0 and some of the considerations that may assist them in the design of their client and/or IPP object implementations.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2639.txt
2640	A			RFCs from 1999							"Internationalization of the File Transfer Protocol" was released in July of 1999 by B. Curtin. This document addresses the internationalization (I18n) of FTP, which includes supporting the multiple character sets and languages found throughout the Internet community.  This is achieved by extending the FTP specification and giving recommendations for proper internationalization support. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2640.txt
2641	A			RFCs from 1999							"Cabletron's VlanHello Protocol Specification Version 4" was released in August of 1999 by D. Ruffen, and D. Hamilton. The VlanHello protocol is part of the InterSwitch Message Protocol (ISMP) which provides interswitch communication between switches running Cabletron's SecureFast VLAN (SFVLAN) product.  Switches use the VlanHello protocol to discover their neighboring switches and establish the topology of the switch fabric.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2641.txt
2642	A			RFCs from 1999							"Cabletron's VLS Protocol Specification" was released in August of 1999 by L. Kane. VLSP provides support for equal-cost multipath routing, and recalculates routes quickly in the face of topological changes, utilizing a minimum of routing protocol traffic.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2642.txt
2643	A			RFCs from 1999							"Cabletron's SecureFast VLAN Operational Model" was released in August of 1999 by J. Yanacek, D. Ruffen, and T. Len. Cabletron's SecureFast VLAN (SFVLAN) product implements a distributed connection-oriented switching protocol that provides fast forwarding of data packets at the MAC layer.  The product uses the concept of virtual LANs (VLANs) to determine the validity of call connection requests and to scope the broadcast of certain flooded messages.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2643.txt
2644	A			RFCs from 1999							"Changing the Default for Directed Broadcasts in Routers" was released in August of 1999 by D. Senie. This document discusses and defines a number of tests that may be used to describe the performance characteristics of a network interconnecting device.  In addition to defining the tests this document also describes specific formats for reporting the results of the tests.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2644.txt
2645	A			RFCs from 1999							"ON-DEMAND MAIL RELAY (ODMR) SMTP with Dynamic IP Addresses" was released in August of 1999 by R. Gellens. This memo proposes a new service, On-Demand Mail Relay (ODMR), which is a profile of SMTP, providing for a secure, extensible, easy to implement approach to the problem. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2645.txt
2646	A			RFCs from 1999							"The Text/Plain Format Parameter" was released in August of 1999 by R. Gellens. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3676">RFC 3676</a>. This memo proposes a new parameter to be used with Text/Plain, and, in the presence of this parameter, the use of trailing whitespace to indicate flowed lines.  This results in an encoding which appears as normal Text/Plain in older implementations, since it is in fact normal Text/Plain. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2646.txt
2647	A			RFCs from 1999							"Benchmarking Terminology for Firewall Performance" was released in August of 1999 by D. Newman. This document defines terms used in measuring the performance of firewalls.  It extends the terminology already used for benchmarking routers and switches with definitions specific to firewalls. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2647.txt
2648	A			RFCs from 1999							"A URN Namespace for IETF Documents" was released in August of 1999 by R. Moats. This document proposes the "ietf" namespace, which consists of the RFC family of documents (RFCs, STDs, FYIs, and BCPs) developed by the IETF and published by the RFC Editor and the minutes of working groups (WG) and birds of a feather (BOF) meetings that occur during IETF conferences. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2648.txt
2649	A			RFCs from 1999							"An LDAP Control and Schema for Holding Operation Signatures" was released in August of 1999 by B. Greenblatt, and P. Richard. This document describes an LDAP message control which allows for the retrieval of digitally signed information.  This document defines an LDAP v3 based mechanism for signing directory operations in order to create a secure journal of changes that have been made to each directory entry.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2649.txt
2650	A			RFCs from 1999							"Using RPSL in Practice" was released in August of 1999 by M. Prior, C. Alaettinoglu, C. Orange, J. Schmitz, and D. Meyer. This document is a tutorial on using the Routing Policy Specification Language (RPSL) to describe routing policies in the Internet Routing Registry (IRR).  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2650.txt
2651	A			RFCs from 1999							"The Architecture of the Common Indexing Protocol (CIP)" was released in August of 1999 by M. Mealling, and J. Allen. This document describes the CIP framework, including its architecture and the protocol specifics of exchanging indices. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2651.txt
2652	A			RFCs from 1999							"MIME Object Definitions for the Common Indexing Protocol (CIP)" was released in August of 1999 by M. Mealling, and J. Allen. This document describes the definitions of those objects as well as the methods and requirements needed to define a new index type. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2652.txt
2653	A			RFCs from 1999							"CIP Transport Protocols" was released in August of 1999 by R. Hedberg, J. Allen, and P. Leach. This document specifies three protocols for transporting CIP requests, responses and index objects, utilizing TCP, mail, and HTTP. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2653.txt
2654	A			RFCs from 1999							"A Tagged Index Object for use in the Common Indexing Protocol" was released in August of 1999 by R. Hedberg, B. Greenblatt, M. Wahl, and R. Moats. This document defines a mechanism by which information servers can exchange indices of information from their databases by making use of the Common Indexing Protocol (CIP).  This document defines the structure of the index information being exchanged, as well as the appropriate meanings for the headers that are defined in the Common Indexing Protocol.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2654.txt
2655	A			RFCs from 1999							"CIP Index Object Format for SOIF Objects" was released in August of 1999 by T. Hardie, M. Schwartz, M. Bowman, D. Wessels, and D. Hardy. This document describes SOIF, the Summary Object Interchange Format, as an index object type in the context of the CIP framework.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2655.txt
2656	A			RFCs from 1999							"Registration Procedures for SOIF Template Types" was released in August of 1999 by T. Hardie. The registration procedure described in this document is specific to SOIF template types.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2656.txt
2657	A			RFCs from 1999							"LDAPv2 Client vs. the Index Mesh" was released in August of 1999 by R. Hedberg. LDAPv2 clients as implemented according to RFC 1777 have no notion on referral.  The integration between such a client and an Index Mesh, as defined by the Common Indexing Protocol, heavily depends on referrals and therefore needs to be handled in a special way.  This document defines one possible way of doing this.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2657.txt
2658	A			RFCs from 1999							"RTP Payload Format for PureVoice(tm) Audio" was released in August of 1999 by K. McKay. This document describes the RTP payload format for PureVoice(tm) Audio. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2658.txt

This memo describes a syntax for securing messages sent using the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP), which forms the basis for the World Wide Web.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2660.txt

2664	A			RFCs from 1999							"FYI on Questions and Answers - Answers to Commonly Asked "New Internet User" Questions" was released in August of 1999 by E. Krol, R. Plzak, and A. Wells. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1594">RFC 1594</a>. This memo provides an overview to the new Internet User.  The intended audience is the common Internet user of today, thus it attempts to provide a more consumer oriented approach to the Internet rather than going into any depth about a topic.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2664.txt

2671	A			RFCs from 1999							"Extension Mechanisms for DNS (EDNS0)" was released in August of 1999 by P. Vixie. The Domain Name System's wire protocol includes a number of fixed fields whose range has been or soon will be exhausted and does not allow clients to advertise their capabilities to servers.  This document describes backward compatible mechanisms for allowing the protocol to grow. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2671.txt
2672	A			RFCs from 1999							"Non-Terminal DNS Name Redirection" was released in August of 1999 by M. Crawford. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+6672">RFC 6672</a>. This document defines a new DNS Resource Record called "DNAME", which provides the capability to map an entire subtree of the DNS name space to another domain. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2672.txt
2673	A			RFCs from 1999							"Binary Labels in the Domain Name System" was released in August of 1999 by M. Crawford. This document defines a "Bit-String Label" which may appear within domain names.  This new label type compactly represents a sequence of "One-Bit Labels" and enables resource records to be stored at any bit- boundary in a binary-named section of the domain name tree. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2673.txt
2674	A			RFCs from 1999							"Definitions of Managed Objects for Bridges with Traffic Classes, Multicast Filtering and Virtual LAN Extensions" was released in August of 1999 by A. Smith, P. 2675	A			RFCs from 1999							"IPv6 Jumbograms" was released in August of 1999 by S. Deering, D. Borman, and R. Hinden. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2147">RFC 2147</a>. This document describes the IPv6 Jumbo Payload option, which provides the means of specifying such large payload lengths.  It also describes the changes needed to TCP and UDP to make use of jumbograms. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2675.txt
2676	A			RFCs from 1999							"QoS Routing Mechanisms and OSPF Extensions" was released in August of 1999 by T. Przygienda, G. Apostolopoulos, R. Guerin, D. Williams, A. Orda, and S. Kama. This memo describes extensions to the OSPF protocol to support QoS routes.  The focus of this document is on the algorithms used to compute QoS routes and on the necessary modifications to OSPF to support this function, e.g., the information needed, its format, how it is distributed, and how it is used by the QoS path selection process.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2676.txt

2678	A			RFCs from 1999							"IPPM Metrics for Measuring Connectivity" was released in September of 1999 by J. Mahdavi, and V. Paxson. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2498">RFC 2498</a>. 2682	A			RFCs from 1999							"Performance Issues in VC-Merge Capable ATM LSRs" was released in September of 1999 by I. Widjaja, and A. Elwalid. This document investigates the impact of VC merging on the additional buffer required for the reassembly buffers and other buffers.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2682.txt
2683	A			RFCs from 1999							"IMAP4 Implementation Recommendations" was released in September of 1999 by B. Leiba. The IMAP4 specification describes a rich protocol for use in building clients and servers for storage, retrieval, and manipulation of electronic mail.  Because the protocol is so rich and has so many implementation choices, there are often trade-offs that must be made and issues that must be considered when designing such clients and servers.  This document attempts to outline these issues and to make recommendations in order to make the end products as interoperable as possible.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2683.txt
2684	A			RFCs from 1999							"Multiprotocol Encapsulation over ATM Adaptation Layer 5" was released in September of 1999 by J. Heinanen, and D. Grossman. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2684.txt

2691	A			RFCs from 1999							"A Memorandum of Understanding for an ICANN Protocol Support Organization" was released in September of 1999 by S. Bradner. 2692	A			RFCs from 1999							"SPKI Requirements" was released in September of 1999 by C. Ellison. The SPKI Working Group first established a list of things one might want to do with certificates (attached at the end of this document), and then summarized that list of desires into requirements.  This document presents that summary of requirements.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2692.txt
2693	A			RFCs from 1999							"SPKI Certificate Theory" was released in September of 1999 by B. Lampson, C. Ellison, B. Frantz, T. Ylonen, B. Thomas, and R. Rivest. This document gives the theory behind SPKI certificates and ACLs without going into technical detail about those structures or their uses.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2693.txt
2694	A			RFCs from 1999							"DNS extensions to Network Address Translators (DNS_ALG)" was released in September of 1999 by P. Srisuresh, G. Tsirtsis, P. Akkiraju, and A. Heffernan. This document identifies the need for DNS extensions to NATs and outlines how a DNS Application Level Gateway (DNS_ALG) can meet the need.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2694.txt
2695	A			RFCs from 1999							"Authentication Mechanisms for ONC RPC" was released in September of 1999 by A. Chiu. 2697	A			RFCs from 1999							"A Single Rate Three Color Marker" was released in September of 1999 by J. Heinanen, and R. Guerin. 2699	A			RFCs from 2000							"Request for Comments Summary RFC Numbers 2600-2699" was released in May of 2000 by S. Ginoza. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2699.txt
2700	A			RFCs from 2000							"Internet Official Protocol Standards" was released in August of 2000 by J. Reynolds, and R. Braden. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2600">RFC 2600</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+2800">RFC 2800</a>. This memo describes the current state of standardization of protocols used in the Internet as determined by the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2700.txt
2701	A			RFCs from 1999							"Nortel Networks Multi-link Multi-node PPP Bundle Discovery Protocol" was released in September of 1999 by G. Malkin. This document specifies a standard way for Multi-link PPP to operate across multiple nodes.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2701.txt
2702	A			RFCs from 1999							"Requirements for Traffic Engineering Over MPLS" was released in September of 1999 by M. O'Dell, D. Awduche, J. McManus, J. Malcolm, and J. Agogbua. This document presents a set of requirements for Traffic Engineering over Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS).  It identifies the functional capabilities required to implement policies that facilitate efficient and reliable network operations in an MPLS domain.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2702.txt
2703	A			RFCs from 1999							"Protocol-independent Content Negotiation Framework" was released in September of 1999 by G. Klyne. This memo sets out terminology, an abstract framework and goals for protocol-independent content negotiation, and identifies some technical issues which may need to be addressed.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2703.txt
2704	A			RFCs from 1999							"The KeyNote Trust-Management System Version 2" was released in September of 1999 by M. Blaze, J. Feigenbaum, A. Keromytis, and J. Ioannidis. This memo describes version 2 of the KeyNote trust-management system.It specifies the syntax and semantics of KeyNote `assertions', describes `action attribute' processing, and outlines the application architecture into which a KeyNote implementation can be fit.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2704.txt
2705	A			RFCs from 1999							"Media Gateway Control Protocol (MGCP) Version 1.0" was released in October of 1999 by I. Elliott, M. Arango, S. Pickett, A. Dugan, and C. Huitema. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3435">RFC 3435</a>. This document describes an application programming interface and a corresponding protocol (MGCP) for controlling Voice over IP (VoIP) Gateways from external call control elements.  MGCP assumes a call control architecture where the call control "intelligence" is outside the gateways and handled by external call control elements.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2705.txt
2706	A			RFCs from 1999							"ECML v1: Field Names for E-Commerce" was released in October of 1999 by D. Eastlake 3rd, and T. Goldstein. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3106">RFC 3106</a>. A standard set of information fields is defined as the first version of an Electronic Commerce Modeling Language (ECML) so that this task can be more easily automated, for example by wallet software that could fill in fields.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2706.txt
2707	A			RFCs from 1999							"Job Monitoring MIB - V1.0" was released in November of 1999 by H. Lewis, T. Hastings, R. Bergman, and S. Isaacson. This document provides a printer industry standard SNMP MIB for (1) monitoring the status and progress of print jobs (2) obtaining resource requirements before a job is processed, (3) monitoring resource consumption while a job is being processed and (4) collecting resource accounting data after the completion of a job.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2707.txt
2708	A			RFCs from 1999							"Job Submission Protocol Mapping Recommendations for the Job Monitoring MIB" was released in November of 1999 by R. Bergman. This document defines the recommended mapping for many currently popular Job submission protocols to objects and attributes in the Job Monitoring MIB.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2708.txt
2709	A			RFCs from 1999							"Security Model with Tunnel-mode IPsec for NAT Domains" was released in October of 1999 by P. Srisuresh. This document describes a security model by which tunnel-mode IPsec security can be architected on NAT devices.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2709.txt
2710	A			RFCs from 1999							"Multicast Listener Discovery (MLD) for IPv6" was released in October of 1999 by W. Fenner, B. Haberman, and S. Deering. This document specifies the protocol used by an IPv6 router to discover the presence of multicast listeners (that is, nodes wishing to receive multicast packets) on its directly attached links, and to discover specifically which multicast addresses are of interest to those neighboring nodes. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2710.txt
2711	A			RFCs from 1999							"IPv6 Router Alert Option" was released in October of 1999 by A. Jackson, and C. Partridge. This memo describes a new IPv6 Hop-by-Hop Option type that alerts transit routers to more closely examine the contents of an IP datagram. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2711.txt
2712	A			RFCs from 1999							"Addition of Kerberos Cipher Suites to Transport Layer Security (TLS)" was released in October of 1999 by A. Medvinsky, and M. Hur. This document proposes the addition of new cipher suites to the TLS protocol to support Kerberos-based authentication. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2712.txt
2713	A			RFCs from 1999							"Schema for Representing Java(tm) Objects in an LDAP Directory" was released in October of 1999 by R. Lee, V. Ryan, and S. Seligman. This document defines the schema for representing Java(tm) objects in an LDAP directory.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2713.txt

This document defines the schema for representing CORBA object references in an LDAP directory.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2714.txt
2715	A			RFCs from 1999							"Interoperability Rules for Multicast Routing Protocols" was released in October of 1999 by D. Thaler. The rules described in this document will allow efficient interoperation among multiple independent multicast routing domains.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2715.txt
2716	A			RFCs from 1999							"PPP EAP TLS Authentication Protocol" was released in October of 1999 by B. Aboba, and D. Simon. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5216">RFC 5216</a>. The Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links.The Extensible Authentication Protocol (EAP) is a PPP extension that provides support for additional authentication methods within PPP.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2716.txt
2717	A			RFCs from 1999							"Registration Procedures for URL Scheme Names" was released in November of 1999 by I. King, and R. Petke. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4395">RFC 4395</a>. This document defines the process by which new URL scheme names are registered.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2717.txt
2718	A			RFCs from 1999							"Guidelines for new URL Schemes" was released in November of 1999 by H. Alvestrand, R. Petke, D. Zigmond, and L. Masinter. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4395">RFC 4395</a>. This document provides guidelines for the definition of new URL schemes.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2718.txt
2719	A			RFCs from 1999							"Framework Architecture for Signaling Transport" was released in October of 1999 by C. Sharp, M. Holdrege, M. Garcia, I. Juhasz, H. Schwarzbauer, L. Coene, I. Rytina, H. Lin, and L. Ong. This document defines an architecture framework and functional requirements for transport of signaling information over IP.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2719.txt
2720	A			RFCs from 1999							"Traffic Flow Measurement: Meter MIB" was released in October of 1999 by N. Brownlee. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2064">RFC 2064</a>. This document defines a Management Information Base (MIB) for use in controlling an RTFM Traffic Meter, in particular for specifying the flows to be measured.  It also provides an efficient mechanism for retrieving flow data from the meter using SNMP.  Security issues concerning the operation of traffic meters are summarised. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2720.txt
2721	A			RFCs from 1999							"RTFM: Applicability Statement" was released in October of 1999 by N. Brownlee. This document provides an overview covering all aspects of Realtime Traffic Flow Measurement, including its area of applicability and its limitations.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2721.txt
2722	A			RFCs from 1999							"Traffic Flow Measurement: Architecture" was released in October of 1999 by C. Mills, G. Ruth, and N. Brownlee. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2063">RFC 2063</a>. This document provides a general framework for describing network traffic flows, presents an architecture for traffic flow measurement and reporting, discusses how this relates to an overall network traffic flow architecture and indicates how it can be used within the Internet.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2722.txt
2723	A			RFCs from 1999							"SRL: A Language for Describing Traffic Flows and Specifying Actions for Flow Groups" was released in October of 1999 by N. Brownlee. This document describes a language for specifying rulesets, i.e.  configuration files which may be loaded into a traffic flow meter so as to specify which traffic flows are measured by the meter, and the information it will store for each flow.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2723.txt
2724	A			RFCs from 1999							"RTFM: New Attributes for Traffic Flow Measurement" was released in October of 1999 by S. Handelman, G. Ruth, N. Brownlee, and S. Stibler. This document discusses RTFM flows and the attributes which they can have, so as to provide a logical framework for extending the architecture by adding new attributes.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2724.txt
2725	A			RFCs from 1999							"Routing Policy System Security" was released in December of 1999 by S. Murphy, C. Villamizar, C. Alaettinoglu, and D. Meyer. The implementation and deployment of a routing policy system must maintain some degree of integrity to be of any operational use.  This document addresses the need to assure integrity of the data by providing an authentication and authorization model. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2725.txt

2727	A			RFCs from 2000							"IAB and IESG Selection, Confirmation, and Recall Process: Operation of the Nominating and Recall Committees" was released in February of 2000 by J. Galvin. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2282">RFC 2282</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3777">RFC 3777</a>. The process by which the members of the IAB and IESG are selected, confirmed, and recalled is specified.  This document is a self- consistent, organized compilation of the process as it was known at the time of publication.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2727.txt

2735	A			RFCs from 1999							"NHRP Support for Virtual Private Networks" was released in December of 1999 by B. Petri, and B. Fox. The NBMA Next Hop Resolution Protocol (NHRP) is used to determine the NBMA subnetwork addresses of the "NBMA next hop" towards a public internetworking layer address.  This document describes the enhancements necessary to enable NHRP to perform the same function for private internetworking layer addresses available within the framework of a Virtual Private Network (VPN) service on a shared NBMA network. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2735.txt

2738	A			RFCs from 1999							"Corrections to "A Syntax for Describing Media Feature Sets"" was released in December of 1999 by G. Klyne. In RFC 2533, "A Syntax for Describing Media Feature Sets", an expression format is presented for describing media feature capabilities using simple media feature tags.  This memo contains two corrections to that specification: one fixes an error in the formal syntax specification, and the other fixes an error in the rules for reducing feature comparison predicates. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2738.txt

2754	A			RFCs from 2000							"RPS IANA Issues" was released in January of 2000 by C. Villamizar, R. Govindan, and C. Alaettinoglu. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+6254">RFC 6254</a>. RPS Security requires certain RPSL objects in the IRR to be hierarchically delegated.  The set of objects that are at the root of this hierarchy needs to be created and digitally signed by IANA.  This paper presents these seed objects and lists operations required from IANA.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2754.txt
2755	A			RFCs from 2000							"Security Negotiation for WebNFS" was released in January of 2000 by A. Chiu, B. Callaghan, and M. Eisler. This document describes a protocol for a WebNFS client (RFC2054) to negotiate the desired security mechanism with a WebNFS server (RFC2055) before the WebNFS client falls back to the MOUNT v3 protocol (RFC1813).  This document is provided so that people can write compatible implementations.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2755.txt
2756	A			RFCs from 2000							"Hyper Text Caching Protocol (HTCP/0.0)" was released in January of 2000 by P. Vixie, and D. Wessels. This document describes HTCP, a protocol for discovering HTTP caches and cached data, managing sets of HTTP caches, and monitoring cache activity.  This is an experimental protocol, one among several proposals to perform these functions.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2756.txt

This document specifies a transition mechanism algorithm in addition to the mechanisms already specified. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2765.txt

This mechanism is only is only for authentication, and has no effect on the protocol encoding and is not designed to provide integrity or confidentiality services. 2821	A			RFCs from 2001							"Simple Mail Transfer Protocol" was released in April of 2001 by J. Klensin. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5321">RFC 5321</a>. 2822	A			RFCs from 2001							"Internet Message Format" was released in April of 2001 by P. Resnick. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+822">RFC 822</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5322">RFC 5322</a>. This document specifies a syntax for text messages that are sent between computer users, within the framework of "electronic mail" messages. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2822.txt
2823	A			RFCs from 2000							"PPP over Simple Data Link (SDL) using SONET/SDH with ATM-like framing" was released in May of 2000 by P. Langner, J. Manchester, E. Hernandez-Valencia, and J. Carlson. This document extends methods found in the Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) and RFCs 1662 and 2615 to include a new encapsulation for PPP called Simple Data Link (SDL).  SDL provides a standard method for transporting multi-protocol datagrams over point-to-point links, and RFCs 1662 and 2615 provide a means to carry PPP over Synchronous Optical Network (SONET) and Synchronous Digital Hierarchy (SDH) circuits.  SDL provides a very low overhead alternative to HDLC-like encapsulation, and can also be used on SONET/SDH links.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2823.txt
2824	A			RFCs from 2000							"Call Processing Language Framework and Requirements" was released in May of 2000 by J. Lennox, and H. Schulzrinne. This document describes an architectural framework we call a processing language, as a simple and standardized way for implementing and deploying Internet telephony.  A large number of the services we wish to make possible for Internet telephony require fairly elaborate combinations of signalling operations, often in network devices, to complete.  It also outlines requirements for such a language.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2824.txt
2825	A			RFCs from 2000							"A Tangled Web: Issues of I18N, Domain Names, and the Other Internet protocols" was released in May of 2000 by IAB, and L. Daigle. This document is a statement by the Internet Architecture Board.  It is not a protocol specification, but an attempt to clarify the range of architectural issues that the internationalization of domain names faces.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2825.txt
2826	A			RFCs from 2000							"IAB Technical Comment on the Unique DNS Root" was released in May of 2000 by Internet Architecture Board. This document discusses the existence of a globally unique public name space in the Internet called the DNS (Domain Name System).  This name space is a hierarchical name space derived from a single, globally unique root.  It is a technical constraint inherent in the design of the DNS.  One root must be supported by a set of coordinated root servers administered by a unique naming authority.  It is not technically feasible for there to be more than one root in the public DNS.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2826.txt
2827	A			RFCs from 2000							"Network Ingress Filtering: Defeating Denial of Service Attacks which employ IP Source Address Spoofing" was released in May of 2000 by P. Ferguson, and D. Senie. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2267">RFC 2267</a>. This paper discusses a simple, effective, and straightforward method for using ingress traffic filtering to prohibit DoS (Denial of Service) attacks which use forged IP addresses to be propagated from 'behind' an Internet Service Provider's (ISP) aggregation point.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2827.txt
2828	A			RFCs from 2000							"Internet Security Glossary" was released in May of 2000 by R. Shirey. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4949">RFC 4949</a>. This Glossary provides abbreviations, explanations, and recommendations for use of information system security terminology.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2828.txt
2829	A			RFCs from 2000							"Authentication Methods for LDAP" was released in May of 2000 by R. Morgan, J. Hodges, H. Alvestrand, and M. Wahl. This document specifies particular combinations of security mechanisms which are required and recommended in LDAP implementations. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2829.txt
2830	A			RFCs from 2000							"Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (v3): Extension for Transport Layer Security" was released in May of 2000 by R. Morgan, J. Hodges, and M. Wahl. This document defines the "Start Transport Layer Security (TLS) Operation" for LDAP. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2830.txt
2831	A			RFCs from 2000							"Using Digest Authentication as a SASL Mechanism" was released in May of 2000 by P. Leach, and C. Newman. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+6331">RFC 6331</a>. This specification defines how HTTP Digest Authentication can be used as a SASL mechanism for any protocol that has a SASL (Simple Authentication and Security Layer) profile. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2831.txt
2832	A			RFCs from 2000							"NSI Registry Registrar Protocol (RRP) Version 1.1.0" was released in May of 2000 by S. Hollenbeck, and M. Srivastava. This document describes a protocol for the registration and management of second level domain names and associated name servers in both generic Top Level Domains (gTLDs) and country code Top Level Domains (ccTLDs).  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2832.txt
2833	A			RFCs from 2000							"RTP Payload for DTMF Digits, Telephony Tones and Telephony Signals" was released in May of 2000 by S. Petrack, and H. Schulzrinne. This memo describes how to carry dual-tone multifrequency (DTMF) signaling, other tone signals and telephony events in RTP packets. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2833.txt
2834	A			RFCs from 2000							"ARP and IP Broadcast over HIPPI-800" was released in May of 2000 by J.-M. Pittet. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1374">RFC 1374</a>. This document specifies a method for resolving IP addresses to ANSI High-Performance Parallel Interface (HIPPI) hardware addresses and for emulating IP broadcast in a logical IP subnet (LIS) as a direct extension of HARP (hardware addresses).  This memo defines a HARP that will interoperate between HIPPI-800 and HIPPI-6400 (also known as Gigabyte System Network, GSN).  This document (when combined with RFC 2067 "IP over HIPPI") obsoletes RFC 1374. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2834.txt
2835	A			RFCs from 2000							"IP and ARP over HIPPI-6400 (GSN)" was released in May of 2000 by J.-M. Pittet. This document further specifies a method for resolving IP addresses to HIPPI-6400 (High-Performance Parallel Interface) hardware addresses (HARP) and for emulating IP broadcast in a logical IP subnet (LIS) as a direct extension of HARP.  Furthermore, it is the goal of this memo to define a IP and HARP that will allow interoperability for HIPPI-800 and HIPPI-6400 equipment both broadcast and non-broadcast capable networks. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2835.txt
2836	A			RFCs from 2000							"Per Hop Behavior Identification Codes" was released in May of 2000 by F. Le Faucheur, B. Carpenter, and S. Brim. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3140">RFC 3140</a>. This document defines a binary encoding to uniquely identify PHBs (Per Hop Behaviors) and/or sets of PHBs in protocol messages. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2836.txt
2837	A			RFCs from 2000							"Definitions of Managed Objects for the Fabric Element in Fibre Channel Standard" was released in May of 2000 by K. Teow. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4044">RFC 4044</a>. This memo defines an extension to the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in TCP/IP-based internets.  In particular, it defines the objects for managing the operations of the Fabric Element portion of the Fibre Channel Standards. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2837.txt
2838	A			RFCs from 2000							"Uniform Resource Identifiers for Television Broadcasts" was released in May of 2000 by D. Zigmond, and M. Vickers. This document describes a widely-implemented URI scheme, as World-Wide Web browsers are starting to appear on a variety of consumer electronic devices, such as television sets and television set-top boxes, which are capable of receiving television programming from either terrestrial broadcast, satellite broadcast, or cable.  In this context there is a need to reference television broadcasts using the URI format described in RFC 2396.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2838.txt
2839	A			RFCs from 2000							"Internet Kermit Service" was released in May of 2000 by J. Altman, and F. da Cruz. This document describes a new file transfer service for the Internet based on Telnet Protocol for option negotiation and Kermit Protocol for file transfer and management.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2839.txt
2840	A			RFCs from 2000							"TELNET KERMIT OPTION" was released in May of 2000 by J. Altman, and F. da Cruz. This document describes an extension to the Telnet protocol to allow the negotiation, coordination, and use of the Kermit file transfer and management protocol over an existing Telnet protocol connection.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2840.txt
2841	A			RFCs from 2000							"IP Authentication using Keyed SHA1 with Interleaved Padding (IP-MAC)" was released in November of 2000 by W. Simpson, and P. Metzger. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1852">RFC 1852</a>. This document describes the use of keyed SHA1 (Secure Hash Algorithm) with the IP Authentication Header.  This memo defines a Historic Document for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2841.txt
2842	A			RFCs from 2000							"Capabilities Advertisement with BGP-4" was released in May of 2000 by J. Scudder, and R. Chandra. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3392">RFC 3392</a>. This document defines new Optional Parameter, called Capabilities, that is expected to facilitate introduction of new capabilities in BGP by providing graceful capability advertisement without requiring that BGP peering be terminated. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2842.txt
2843	A			RFCs from 2000							"Proxy-PAR" was released in May of 2000 by T. Przygienda, and P. Droz. The intention of this document is to provide general information about Proxy-PAR (PNNI Augmented Routing). [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2843.txt
2844	A			RFCs from 2000							"OSPF over ATM and Proxy-PAR" was released in May of 2000 by T. Przygienda, P. Droz, and R. Haas. This memo specifies, for OSPF implementors and users, mechanisms describing how the protocol operates in ATM networks over PVC (Permanent Virtual Connections) and SVC (Switched Virtual Circuit) meshes with the presence of Proxy-PAR (PNNI Augmented Routing).  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2844.txt
2845	A			RFCs from 2000							"Secret Key Transaction Authentication for DNS (TSIG)" was released in May of 2000 by P. Vixie, D. Eastlake 3rd, O. Gudmundsson, and B. Wellington. This protocol allows for transaction level authentication using shared secrets and one way hashing.  It can be used to authenticate dynamic updates as coming from an approved client, or to authenticate responses as coming from an approved recursive name server. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2845.txt
2846	A			RFCs from 2000							"GSTN Address Element Extensions in E-mail Services" was released in June of 2000 by C. Allocchio. This memo defines a full syntax for a specific application in which there is a need to represent GSTN (Global Switched Telephone Network) addressing and Internet addressing. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2846.txt
2847	A			RFCs from 2000							"LIPKEY - A Low Infrastructure Public Key Mechanism Using SPKM" was released in June of 2000 by M. Eisler. This memorandum describes a method whereby one can use GSS-API (Generic Security Service Application Program Interface) to supply a secure channel between a client and server, authenticating the client with a password, and a server with a public key certificate. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2847.txt

2855	A			RFCs from 2000							"DHCP for IEEE 1394" was released in June of 2000 by K. Fujisawa. This memo describes specific usage of some fields of DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) messages.  IEEE Std 1394-1995 is a standard for a High Performance Serial Bus.  Since 1394 uses a different link-layer addressing method than conventional IEEE802/Ethernet, the usage of some fields must be clarified to achieve interoperability. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2855.txt

2861	A			RFCs from 2000							"TCP Congestion Window Validation" was released in June of 2000 by S. Floyd, J. Padhye, and M. Handley. This document describes a simple modification to TCP's congestion control algorithms to decay the congestion window cwnd after the transition from a sufficiently-long application-limited period, while using the slow-start threshold ssthresh to save information about the previous value of the congestion window.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2861.txt

2863	A			RFCs from 2000							"The Interfaces Group MIB" was released in June of 2000 by F. Kastenholz, and K. McCloghrie. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2233">RFC 2233</a>. This memo discusses the 'interfaces' group of MIB-II, especially the experience gained from the definition of numerous media-specific MIB modules for use in conjunction with the 'interfaces' group for managing various sub-layers beneath the internetwork-layer. RSVP signaling messages typically include policy data objects, which in turn contain policy elements.  Policy elements may describe user and/or application information, which may be used by RSVP aware network elements to apply appropriate policy decisions to a traffic flow.  This memo details the usage of policy elements that provide application information. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2872.txt

It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+1933">RFC 1933</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4213">RFC 4213</a>. This document specifies IPv4 compatibility mechanisms that can be implemented by IPv6 hosts and routers. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2893.txt
2894	A			RFCs from 2000							"Router Renumbering for IPv6" was released in August of 2000 by M. Crawford. This document defines a mechanism called Router Renumbering ("RR") which allows address prefixes on routers to be configured and reconfigured almost as easily as the combination of Neighbor Discovery and Address Autoconfiguration works for hosts. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2894.txt
2895	A			RFCs from 2000							"Remote Network Monitoring MIB Protocol Identifier Reference" was released in August of 2000 by C. Bucci, A. Bierman, and R. Iddon. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2074">RFC 2074</a>. This memo defines a notation describing protocol layers in a protocol encapsulation, specifically for use in encoding ``INDEX`` values for the protocolDirTable, found in the RMON-2 MIB. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2895.txt
2896	A			RFCs from 2000							"Remote Network Monitoring MIB Protocol Identifier Macros" was released in August of 2000 by C. Bucci, A. Bierman, and R. Iddon. This memo contains various protocol identifier examples, which can be used to produce valid protocolDirTable ``INDEX`` encodings, as defined by the Remote Network Monitoring MIB and the RMON Protocol Identifier Reference.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2896.txt
2897	A			RFCs from 2000							"Proposal for an MGCP Advanced Audio Package" was released in August of 2000 by D. Cromwell. This document is a proposal to add a new event/signal package to the MGCP (Media Gateway Control Protocol) protocol to control an ARF (Audio Resource Function) which may reside on a Media Gateway or specialized Audio Server.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2897.txt
2898	A			RFCs from 2000							"PKCS #5: Password-Based Cryptography Specification Version 2.0" was released in September of 2000 by B. Kaliski. This document provides recommendations for the implementation of password-based cryptography, covering key derivation functions, encryption schemes, message-authentication schemes, and ASN.1 syntax identifying the techniques.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2898.txt
2899	A			RFCs from 2001							"Request for Comments Summary RFC Numbers 2800-2899" was released in May of 2001 by S. Ginoza. 	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2899.txt
2900	A			RFCs from 2001							"Internet Official Protocol Standards" was released in August of 2001 by J. Reynolds, S. Ginoza, and R. Braden. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2800">RFC 2800</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3000">RFC 3000</a>. This memo contains a snapshot of the state of standardization of protocols used in the Internet as of July 17, 2001.  It lists official protocol standards and Best Current Practice RFCs; it is not a complete index to the RFC series.  This memo is an Internet Standard.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2900.txt
2901	A			RFCs from 2000							"Guide to Administrative Procedures of the Internet Infrastructure" was released in August of 2000 by J. Klensin, R. Bush, S. Huter, and Z. Wenzel. This document describes the administrative procedures for networks seeking to connect to the global Internet.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2901.txt
2902	A			RFCs from 2000							"Overview of the 1998 IAB Routing Workshop" was released in August of 2000 by C. Perkins, S. Hares, S. Deering, and R. Perlman. This document is an overview of a Routing workshop held by the Internet Architecture Board (IAB) during March 25-27, 1998.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2902.txt
2903	A			RFCs from 2000							"Generic AAA Architecture" was released in August of 2000 by D. Spence, G. Gross, L. Gommans, J. Vollbrecht, and C. de Laat. This memo proposes an Authentication, Authorization, Accounting (AAA) architecture that would incorporate a generic AAA server along with an application interface to a set of Application Specific Modules that could perform application specific AAA functions.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2903.txt
2904	A			RFCs from 2000							"AAA Authorization Framework" was released in August of 2000 by D. Spence, G. Gross, M. Holdrege, L. Gommans, P. Calhoun, B. de Bruijn, J. Vollbrecht, S. Farrell, and C. de Laat. This memo serves as the base requirements for Authorization of Internet Resources and Services (AIRS).  It presents an architectural framework for understanding the authorization of Internet resources and services and derives requirements for authorization protocols.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2904.txt
2905	A			RFCs from 2000							"AAA Authorization Application Examples" was released in August of 2000 by D. Spence, G. Gross, M. Holdrege, L. Gommans, P. Calhoun, B. de Bruijn, J. Vollbrecht, S. Farrell, and C. de Laat. This memo describes several examples of applications requiring authorization.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2905.txt
2906	A			RFCs from 2000							"AAA Authorization Requirements" was released in August of 2000 by D. Spence, G. Gross, M. Holdrege, L. Gommans, P. Calhoun, B. de Bruijn, J. Vollbrecht, S. Farrell, and C. de Laat. This document specifies the requirements that Authentication Authorization Accounting (AAA) protocols must meet in order to support authorization services in the Internet.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2906.txt

2908	A			RFCs from 2000							"The Internet Multicast Address Allocation Architecture" was released in September of 2000 by D. Thaler, D. Estrin, and M. Handley. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+6308">RFC 6308</a>. This document proposes a multicast address allocation architecture (MALLOC) for the Internet.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2908.txt
2909	A			RFCs from 2000							"The Multicast Address-Set Claim (MASC) Protocol" was released in September of 2000 by D. Thaler, P. Radoslavov, R. Govindan, S. Kumar, M. Handley, and D. Estrin. This document describes the Multicast Address-Set Claim (MASC) protocol which can be used for inter-domain multicast address set allocation.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2909.txt

2913	A			RFCs from 2000							"MIME Content Types in Media Feature Expressions" was released in September of 2000 by G. Klyne. 2914	A			RFCs from 2000							"Congestion Control Principles" was released in September of 2000 by S. Floyd. The goal of this document is to explain the need for congestion control in the Internet, and to discuss what constitutes correct congestion control.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2914.txt
2915	A			RFCs from 2000							"The Naming Authority Pointer (NAPTR) DNS Resource Record" was released in September of 2000 by M. Mealling, and R. Daniel. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2915.txt
2916	A			RFCs from 2000							"E.164 number and DNS" was released in September of 2000 by P. Faltstrom. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3761">RFC 3761</a>. 2918	A			RFCs from 2000							"Route Refresh Capability for BGP-4" was released in September of 2000 by E. Chen. This document defines a new Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) capability termed 'Route Refresh Capability', which would allow the dynamic exchange of route refresh request between BGP speakers and subsequent re-advertisement of the respective Adj-RIB-Out. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2918.txt
2919	A			RFCs from 2001							"List-Id: A Structured Field and Namespace for the Identification of Mailing Lists" was released in March of 2001 by G. Wenger, and R. Chandhok. Software that handles electronic mailing list messages (servers and user agents) needs a way to reliably identify messages that belong to a particular mailing list.  With the advent of list management headers, it has become even more important to provide a unique identifier for a mailing list regardless of the particular host that serves as the list processor at any given time. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2919.txt
2920	A			RFCs from 2000							"SMTP Service Extension for Command Pipelining" was released in September of 2000 by N. Freed. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2197">RFC 2197</a>. This memo defines an extension to the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) service whereby a server can indicate the extent of its ability to accept multiple commands in a single Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) send operation. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2920.txt
2921	A			RFCs from 2000							"6BONE pTLA and pNLA Formats (pTLA)" was released in September of 2000 by B. Fink. 2922	A			RFCs from 2000							"Physical Topology MIB" was released in September of 2000 by A. Bierman, and K. Jones. This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2922.txt
2923	A			RFCs from 2000							"TCP Problems with Path MTU Discovery" was released in September of 2000 by K. Lahey. This memo catalogs several known Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) implementation problems dealing with Path Maximum Transmission Unit Discovery (PMTUD), including the long-standing black hole problem, stretch acknowlegements (ACKs) due to confusion between Maximum Segment Size (MSS) and segment size, and MSS advertisement based on PMTU.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2923.txt

2936	A			RFCs from 2000							"HTTP MIME Type Handler Detection" was released in September of 2000 by C. Smith, D. Soroka, and D. Eastlake 3rd. Entities composing web pages to provide services over the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) frequently have the problem of not knowing what Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) types have handlers installed at a user's browser.  This document summarizes reasonable techniques to solve this problem for most of the browsers actually deployed on the Internet as of early 2000.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2936.txt

This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2958.txt
2959	A			RFCs from 2000							"Real-Time Transport Protocol Management Information Base" was released in October of 2000 by B. Strahm, M. Baugher, and I. Suconick. This memo defines a portion of the Management Information Base (MIB) for use with network management protocols in the Internet community. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2959.txt
2960	A			RFCs from 2000							"Stream Control Transmission Protocol" was released in October of 2000 by R. Stewart, M. Kalla, V. Paxson, I. Rytina, K. Morneault, C. Sharp, L. Zhang, Q. Xie, H. Schwarzbauer, and T. Taylor. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+4960">RFC 4960</a>. This document describes the Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP). [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2960.txt
2961	A			RFCs from 2001							"RSVP Refresh Overhead Reduction Extensions" was released in April of 2001 by F. Tommasi, P. Pan, S. Molendini, L. Berger, D. Gan, and G. Swallow. This document describes a number of mechanisms that can be used to reduce processing overhead requirements of refresh messages, eliminate the state synchronization latency incurred when an RSVP (Resource ReserVation Protocol) message is lost and, when desired, refreshing state without the transmission of whole refresh messages. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2961.txt
2962	A			RFCs from 2000							"An SNMP Application Level Gateway for Payload Address Translation" was released in October of 2000 by D. Raz, B. Sugla, and J. Schoenwaelder. This document describes the ALG (Application Level Gateway) for the SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) by which IP (Internet Protocol) addresses in the payload of SNMP packets are statically mapped from one group to another.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2962.txt
2963	A			RFCs from 2000							"A Rate Adaptive Shaper for Differentiated Services" was released in October of 2000 by S. De Cnodder, and O. Bonaventure. This memo describes several Rate Adaptive Shapers (RAS) that can be used in combination with the single rate Three Color Markers (srTCM) and the two rate Three Color Marker (trTCM) described in RFC2697 and RFC2698, respectively.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2963.txt
2964	A			RFCs from 2000							"Use of HTTP State Management" was released in October of 2000 by K. Moore, and N. Freed. This memo identifies specific uses of Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) State Management protocol which are either (a) not recommended by the IETF, or (b) believed to be harmful, and discouraged.  This memo also details additional privacy considerations which are not covered by the HTTP State Management protocol specification.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2964.txt
2965	A			RFCs from 2000							"HTTP State Management Mechanism" was released in October of 2000 by D. Kristol, and L. Montulli. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2109">RFC 2109</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+6265">RFC 6265</a>. This document specifies a way to create a stateful session with Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) requests and responses. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2965.txt
2966	A			RFCs from 2000							"Domain-wide Prefix Distribution with Two-Level IS-IS" was released in October of 2000 by T. Przygienda, T. Li, and H. Smit. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+5302">RFC 5302</a>. This document describes extensions to the Intermediate System to Intermediate System (IS-IS) protocol to support optimal routing within a two-level domain.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2966.txt
2967	A			RFCs from 2000							"TISDAG - Technical Infrastructure for Swedish Directory Access Gateways" was released in October of 2000 by R. Hedberg, and L. Daigle. The overarching goal of this project is to develop the necessary technical infrastructure to provide a single-access-point service for searching for whitepages information on Swedish Internet users.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2967.txt
2968	A			RFCs from 2000							"Mesh of Multiple DAG servers - Results from TISDAG" was released in October of 2000 by T. Eklof, and L. Daigle. This document defines the basic principle for establishing a mesh, that interoperating services should exchange index objects, according to the architecture of the mesh (e.g., hierarchical, or graph-like, preferably without loops!).  The Common Indexing Protocol (CIP) is designed to facilitate the creation not only of query referral indexes, but also of meshes of (loosely) affiliated referral indexes.  The purpose of such a mesh of servers is to implement some kind of distributed sharing of indexing and/or searching tasks across different servers.  So far, the TISDAG (Technical Infrastructure for Swedish Directory Access Gateways) project has focused on creating a single referral index; the obvious next step is to integrate that into a larger set of interoperating services.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2968.txt
2969	A			RFCs from 2000							"Wide Area Directory Deployment - Experiences from TISDAG" was released in October of 2000 by T. Eklof, and L. Daigle. This document catalogues some of the experiences gained in developing the necessary infrastructure for a national (i.e., multi-organizational) directory service and pilot deployment of the service in an environment with off-the-shelf directory service products.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2969.txt
2970	A			RFCs from 2000							"Architecture for Integrated Directory Services - Result from TISDAG" was released in October of 2000 by T. Eklof, and L. Daigle. Drawing from experiences with the TISDAG (Technical Infrastructure for Swedish Directory Access Gateways) project, this document outlines an approach to providing the necessary infrastructure for integrating such widely-scattered servers into a single service, rather than attempting to mandate a single protocol and schema set for all participating servers to use.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2970.txt
2971	A			RFCs from 2000							"IMAP4 ID extension" was released in October of 2000 by T. Showalter. This document describes an ID extension which will enable Internet Message Access Protocol - Version 4rev1 (IMAP4rev1) to advertise what program a client or server uses to provide service.  The ID extension allows the server and client to exchange identification information on their implementation in order to make bug reports and usage statistics more complete. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2971.txt
2972	A			RFCs from 2000							"Context and Goals for Common Name Resolution" was released in October of 2000 by M. Mealling, N. Popp, L. Masinter, and K. Sollins. 2973	A			RFCs from 2000							"IS-IS Mesh Groups" was released in October of 2000 by J. Parker, D. Katz, and R. Balay. This document describes a mechanism to reduce redundant packet transmissions for the Intermediate System to Intermediate System (IS-IS) Routing protocol, as described in ISO 10589.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2973.txt
2974	A			RFCs from 2000							"Session Announcement Protocol" was released in October of 2000 by C. Perkins, E. Whelan, and M. Handley. This document describes version 2 of the multicast session directory announcement protocol, Session Announcement Protocol (SAP), and the related issues affecting security and scalability that should be taken into account by implementors.  This memo defines an Experimental Protocol for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2974.txt
2975	A			RFCs from 2000							"Introduction to Accounting Management" was released in October of 2000 by D. Harrington, B. Aboba, and J. Arkko. This document describes and discusses the issues involved in the design of the modern accounting systems.  The field of Accounting Management is concerned with the collection the collection of resource consumption data for the purposes of capacity and trend analysis, cost allocation, auditing, and billing.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2975.txt
2976	A			RFCs from 2000							"The SIP INFO Method" was released in October of 2000 by S. Donovan. It is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+6086">RFC 6086</a>. This document proposes an extension to the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP).  This extension adds the INFO method to the SIP protocol.  The intent of the INFO method is to allow for the carrying of session related control information that is generated during a session. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2976.txt
2977	A			RFCs from 2000							"Mobile IP Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting Requirements" was released in October of 2000 by C. Perkins, S. Jacobs, T. Hiller, and S. Glass. This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2977.txt
2978	A			RFCs from 2000							"IANA Charset Registration Procedures" was released in October of 2000 by J. Postel, and N. Freed. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2278">RFC 2278</a>. Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) and various other Internet protocols are capable of using many different charsets.  This in turn means that the ability to label different charsets is essential.  This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2978.txt

In this document, a number of popular extensions to the Network News Transfer Protocol (NNTP) protocol defined in RFC 977 are documented and discussed.  While this document is not intended to serve as a standard of any kind, it will hopefully serve as a reference document for future implementers of the NNTP protocol.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2980.txt

2989	A			RFCs from 2000							"Criteria for Evaluating AAA Protocols for Network Access" was released in November of 2000 by M. Munson, P. Calhoun, B. Aboba, X. Chen, M. Beadles, B. Patil, C. Perkins, E. Jaques, B. Hirschman, S. Sivalingham, S. Baba, S. Jacobs, G. Zorn, D. Mitton, E. Campbell, Y. Xu, B. Lim, S. Glass, T. Hiller, H. Shiino, M. Lipford, H. Koo, G. Dommety, P. McCann, R. 2990	A			RFCs from 2000							"Next Steps for the IP QoS Architecture" was released in November of 2000 by G. Huston. This document highlights the outstanding architectural issues relating to the deployment and use of QoS mechanisms within internet networks, noting those areas where further standards work may assist with the deployment of QoS internets.  This document is the outcome of a collaborative exercise on the part of the Internet Architecture Board.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2990.txt
2991	A			RFCs from 2000							"Multipath Issues in Unicast and Multicast Next-Hop Selection" was released in November of 2000 by D. Thaler, and C. Hopps. The effect of multipath routing on a forwarder is that the forwarder potentially has several next-hops for any given destination and must use some method to choose which next-hop should be used for a given data packet.  This memo summarizes current practices, problems, and solutions.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2991.txt
2992	A			RFCs from 2000							"Analysis of an Equal-Cost Multi-Path Algorithm" was released in November of 2000 by C. Hopps. Equal-cost multi-path (ECMP) is a routing technique for routing packets along multiple paths of equal cost.  The forwarding engine identifies paths by next-hop.  When forwarding a packet the router must decide which next-hop (path) to use.  This document gives an analysis of one method for making that decision.  The analysis includes the performance of the algorithm and the disruption caused by changes to the set of next-hops.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2992.txt
2993	A			RFCs from 2000							"Architectural Implications of NAT" was released in November of 2000 by T. Hain. This document discusses some of the architectural implications and guidelines for implementations of Network Address Translation (NAT).  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2993.txt
2994	A			RFCs from 2000							"A Description of the MISTY1 Encryption Algorithm" was released in November of 2000 by M. Matsui, and H. Ohta. This document describes a secret-key cryptosystem MISTY1, which is block cipher with a 128-bit key, a 64-bit block and a variable number of rounds.  It documents the algorithm description including key scheduling part and data randomizing part.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2994.txt
2995	A			RFCs from 2000							"Pre-Spirits Implementations of PSTN-initiated Services" was released in November of 2000 by S. Hadvani, S. Ago, J. Hwang, M. Weissman, S. Nyckelgard, I. Faynberg, J. Voelker, L. Robart, W. Zhang, S. Moeenuddin, S. Rhim, J. Yoakum, and H. Lu. This document describes four existing implementations of SPIRITS-like services from Korea Telecom, Lucent Technologies, NEC, and Telia in cooperation with Nortel Networks.  SPIRITS-like services are those originating in the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) and necessitating the interactions of the Internet and PSTN.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2995.txt
2996	A			RFCs from 2000							"Format of the RSVP DCLASS Object" was released in November of 2000 by Y. Bernet. This document specifies the format of the DCLASS object and briefly discusses its use. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2996.txt
2997	A			RFCs from 2000							"Specification of the Null Service Type" was released in November of 2000 by A. Smith, Y. Bernet, and B. Davie. The Null Service allows applications to identify themselves to network Quality of Service (QoS) policy agents, using RSVP signaling.  However, it does not require them to specify resource requirements.  QoS policy agents in the network respond by applying QoS policies appropriate for the application (as determined by the network administrator).  This mode of RSVP usage is particularly applicable to networks that combine differentiated service (diffserv) QoS mechanisms with RSVP signaling.  In this environment, QoS policy agents may direct the signaled application's traffic to a particular diffserv class of service. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2997.txt
2998	A			RFCs from 2000							"A Framework for Integrated Services Operation over Diffserv Networks" was released in November of 2000 by Y. Bernet, P. Ford, M. Speer, R. Yavatkar, L. Zhang, F. Baker, J. Wroclawski, E. Felstaine, B. Davie, and R. Braden. This document describes a framework by which Integrated Services may be supported over Diffserv networks.  This memo provides information for the Internet community.	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc2998.txt

3000	A			RFCs from 2001							"Internet Official Protocol Standards" was released in November of 2001 by J. Reynolds, S. Ginoza, L. Shiota, and R. Braden. It obsoletes <a href="/?q=RFC+2900">RFC 2900</a> and is obsoleted by <a href="/?q=RFC+3300">RFC 3300</a>. This memo contains a snapshot of the state of standardization of protocols used in the Internet as of October 25, 2001.  It lists official protocol standards and Best Current Practice RFCs; it is not a complete index to the RFC series.  The latest version of this memo is designated STD 1. [STANDARDS-TRACK]	http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3000.txt
